characters: EXT, RAILPOAD TRACKS AND WOODED MEADOW
EXT, ANOTHER TYPE OF GERMAN COUNTRYSIDE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: SENTRY TOWER - SENTRY 8 ‘ The fifteen foot sentry tower is @ little more than ae covered platform with an armed - always armed - uniformed sentry. Searchlight. Telephone. Around the SENTRY'S neck is a pair of bincculars. He looks off, reacts.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The convoy approaches through monotonous, desolate pine woods.

dialogues.speaker: THE SENTRY 10.
dialogues.text: immediately blows his whistle. This is taken up by others. Over comes gutteral German commands. FROM tOwER - THE CONVOY 11 grinds through the barbed gate and begins forming up in the vast, desolate camp area. 300 yards by 300 yards. Dirt. Surrounded by nine foot barbed wire double fences. Impossible to scale. Machine-gunned sentry towers every 150 yards. Fifteen new barrack huts. Hundreds of guarcs, "ferrets" (Prison spies) converge on the twenty trucks -~ all heavily armed.

dialogues.speaker: TRUCK . 12
dialogues.text: The canvas flap is opened and the POW's begin to get out. All tired. Dressed in haphazard uniforms. Carrying pots, pans, dedrolls, boxes; one hes a guitar, another a teapot; some carry nothing; all are RAF officers. They stare arourd silently, appalled by the extent of security rescrictions. .

dialogues.speaker: ANOTHER TRUCK 13
dialogues.text: More ferrets and guards get the ‘silent. POW's into some semblance of order and line them up to be searched. The first man, EAMES - a young Fiight Lieutenant - stumbles, drops his pack, sourly bends down to pick it up.

dialogues.speaker: HIS HANDS .
dialogues.text: as he passes a pair of wire cutters to the next in jane. The wire cutters disappear. oe

dialogues.speaker: EAMES , 15
dialogues.text: straightens and allows KRAMER, a German ferret, to search him. Very efficiently. Kramer finds a jack knife, pockets it happiiy. As he nods for Eames to move out... = , CLOSE SHOT. - ‘HANDS 16 the wire cutters are deftly passed over once more - disaypear. .

dialogues.speaker: MAIN GATE
dialogues.text: grinds through and the heavily armed guards close the evil barbed wire gate with finality.

dialogues.speaker: THE GREAT ESCAPE
dialogues.text: and interrperse the remaining credits over:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The ferrets searching... officers streaming off to find quarters...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tiny cubicle rooms - leng corridors... officers tapping walls... peering under bunks... into attic traps... settling bedding straight... casing the joint actively. and passively...

dialogues.speaker: DANNY VELINSKI 20
dialogues.text: a Polish RAF officer, chunky, squats on the dirt near the "trip wire" with WILLIE DIX, a young Englishman.

dialogues.speaker: ANOTHER PART OF COMPOUND 21
dialogues.text: near the trip wire is HILTS, a taut American. He wears a baseball mitt and stares out of the camp thoughtfully. Beside him is GOFF, another American flyer.

dialogues.speaker: NEAR A TRUCK
dialogues.text: a tall, impeccably dressed American, is thoughtfully watching the German truck driver tinkering. with the engine.

dialogues.speaker: INT, BARRACK ROOM
dialogues.text: DaI NIMMO 23 a small, dark Welshman, is getting his bunk shipshape in the cursing, shoving mass of men. Nearby is CAVENDISH, a strong tall man with a Flamboyant moustache.

dialogues.speaker: MAJOR MERIVALE 24
dialogues.text: His age is insharp contrast to the others. He steeples his hands thoughtfully, watching some pathetic Russian slave laborers tidy the remains of cut-down trees. His hands are strangely twisted, two fingers almost frozen into a perpetual V for victory sign.

dialogues.speaker: NEAR THE COOKHOUSE
dialogues.text: An Australian contemplates.pots.and. pans. Then exits.

dialogues.speaker: NEAR THE FENCE
dialogues.text: strolls along with ERIC ASHLEY-PITT, Lt. Commander RN, Fleet Air Arm. As they walk, they scrutinize the camp. Concerned.

dialogues.speaker: NEAR THE MAIN GATE
dialogues.text: A tough professional soldier - STRACHWITZ - escorts GROUP CAPTAIN RAMSEY past the sentries at the gate. Ramsey is erect, dressed in battered RAF uniform, a scarf at his neck; he limps and walks with a stick. Strachwitz leads him to the Headquarters Building just outside the compound proper.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Strachwitz walks up the steps with Ramsey.

dialogues.speaker: CAPTAIN POSEN 29
dialogues.text: is small, very neat, very efficient. He watches from a window then turns as Strachwitz enters, salutes. THE CREDITS END.

dialogues.speaker: STRACHWITZ
dialogues.text: Der Herr Staffel-Kapitaen Ramsey. ©

dialogues.speaker: POSEN
dialogues.text: Good morning, Group Captain. I am Captain Posen, Colonel Von Luger's adjutant. Since, as Senior British Officer, you are to be liaison between the prisoners.eand the Colonel, he wishes to make clear to you certain matters of. -- | (groping) -- the word is 'policy'? i

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ramsey nods politely and Posen turns, Imocks on the door.

dialogues.speaker: VON LUGER'S VOICE
dialogues.text: Herein.

dialogues.speaker: STRACHWITZ 30
dialogues.text: holds the door open courteously for Ramsey and Posen.

dialogues.speaker: VON LUGER 31
dialogues.text: is a Prussian Luftwaffe officer. Colonel. Immaculate. Many medal ribbons. Some from World War One. Of an age with Ramsey. He stands near a window. Big desk - peerless. Von Luger returns Ramsey's casual salute punctiliously.

dialogues.speaker: VON LUGER
dialogues.text: I am Colonel Von Luger, the Commandant, : (politely) Please sit down. Strachwitz stands stiff at attention. Ramsey sits. Posen stands. Von Luger sits behind the desk. On it as a large file. He passes cigarettes. A long silence.

dialogues.speaker: VON LUGER
dialogues.text: In the past four years the Reich has been forced to spend an enormous amount of time, energy man power and equipment hunting down escaping officer POW's.

dialogues.speaker: RAMSEY
dialogues.text: (politely) It's rather nice to know you're “wanted, isn't it, Colonel Von Luger? . .

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: With us it is not a matter for levity. There will be no escapes from this camp.

dialogues.speaker: RAMSEY
dialogues.text: (wearily) It is-.the sworn duty of officers to try to escape. If they can't, - it is their sworn duty to cause : the enemy to use an inordinate number of soldiers to guard them and their sworn duty to harass the enemy to the best of their ability.

dialogues.speaker: VON LUGER
dialogues.text: I know. The men under your authority have been most successful. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: a

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: He glances at the file - a photo and a sheet catches his eye - picks it up.

dialogues.speaker: VON LUGER
dialogues.text: (irritably) . Merivale, for example. Caught at Dunkirk. Escaped. Recaptured. Escaped. Recaptured. He even tried to jump out of the train coming here. Seventeen attempted escapes - this is close to insanity.

dialogues.speaker: RAMSEY
dialogues.text: Quite.

dialogues.speaker: VON LUGER
dialogues.text: He was in the First World War -- and he's not even an Air Force Officer.

dialogues.speaker: RAMSEY
dialogues.text: He's a major in the British Expeditionary Force. As you said. Captured at Dunkirk. - (quizzically) Colonel, do you expect officers to forget their duty? (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: VON LUGER
dialogues.text: It is because we expect the orposite that we have brought you here. This camp embodies all we have learned of security measures. We have in effect put all our rotten eggs in one basket and -- believe me, Group Captain -- we intend to watch this basket carefully.

dialogues.speaker: RAMSEY
dialogues.text: (after pause) Very wise.

dialogues.speaker: VON LUGER
dialogues.text: You will not be denied the usual facilities. Sports, a library, a camp theatre. And for gardening, we will entrust you - during the day - with tools. But please -- (a sardonic grin) -- use them for gardening. Devote | your energies to these things. Give ur your hopeless attempts to escape and with intelligent cooperation - we may all sit out the war as comfortably as possible. There is a moment's pause as, he waits for some response from Ramsey, then -- : ° . aren . |

dialogues.speaker: VON LUGER
dialogues.text: (continuing) Are there any questions?

dialogues.speaker: RAMSEY
dialogues.text: Have you ever been caged, Colonel - Von Luger? They stare at each other.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: are near the warning wire under the watchful eyes of the sentries and goonbox men. Danny picks up some dirt, lets the sandy soil dribble through his fingers, shakes his head. ( CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: O . DANNY
dialogues.text: CO Too much sand. Willie is studying the woods beyond the fence.

dialogues.speaker: WILLIE
dialogues.text: How far are the trees?

dialogues.speaker: DANNY
dialogues.text: Over a hundred feet.

dialogues.speaker: WILLIE
dialogues.text: (does some mental triangulation) Less.

dialogues.speaker: DANNY
dialogues.text: Still a long way to dig.

dialogues.speaker: WILLIE
dialogues.text: We'll get Cavendish tc make a survey. They stroll along.

dialogues.speaker: . WILLIE
dialogues.text: Oo I wish "Big X" were here. As I'm. senior tunnel expert, I'm" afraid I might be elected.

dialogues.speaker: . DANNY
dialogues.text: You'd make a good "Big X", Willie.

dialogues.speaker: WILLIE
dialogues.text: (shakes his head) No. That takes a- different sort of mind.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (looks about to see if he could possibly be overheard) Do you think "Big X" got away?

dialogues.speaker: WILLIE
dialogues.text: No. He'd've sent us word, somehow, if he had.

dialogues.speaker: DANNY
dialogues.text: You think the Gestapo has him?

dialogues.speaker: WILLIE
dialogues.text: O That - or he's dead.

dialogues.speaker: RUSSIAN PRISONERS 33
dialogues.text: stand huddled under guard in a group near the Vorlager, morose and dirty. Some wear long Russian Army greatcoais, but most are barely clothed in motley rags. Some carry tools - axes, pitchforks. Some are still finishing their job, tossing branches into the trucks. Merivale joins a group of POW's nearby. Sedgwick, the lanky Australian, is among them.

dialogues.speaker: MERIVALE
dialogues.text: (urgently) Hold these for me in case I should return. The FOU's react immediately, cover him as he takes off his hat and other identifying clothes, gives them to the men, who pat them on.

dialogues.speaker: MERIVALE
dialogues.text: (whispers ) Now if you would just put on some sort of brief show for the goons.

dialogues.speaker: SEDGWICK
dialogues.text: What'll it be - "Battle Royal"? "The Mad Prisoner"? "The Busker"? "Fisticuffs"?

dialogues.speaker: MERIVALE
dialogues.text: Fisticuffs would be jolly ‘good. - Sedgviick grabs Merivaie's sweater from HAYNES, the man holding it.

dialogues.speaker: SEDGWICK
dialogues.text: It's mine, you bloody Limey!

dialogues.speaker: HAYNES 4
dialogues.text: (shouting) no -It's mine you bloody, illiterate | Aussie son of a... | Sedgwick heuls off a haymaker and they go at it. Haynes lands an apparently smashing blow on Sedgwick who goes down. Haynes leaps on him and they struggle - other POW's egg them on excitedly. Guards and ferrets com. over to break ur the fight.

dialogues.speaker: MERIVALE 34
dialogues.text: slips in with the Russians, quickly dirties his hands and face.

dialogues.speaker: SEDGWICK
dialogues.text: is lyinz on his face still being pummelled by Haynes, who refuses to be dragged off by the guards. Sedgwick notes Merivale's- strategy with interest.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: During all this, IVES, the jockey-sized New Zealander, vaults into the back of the first truck and disappears into the branches.

dialogues.speaker: WILLIE AND DANNY 37
dialogues.text: dive into the next truck, disappear under a camouflage ef branches.

dialogues.speaker: BY THE VORLAGER AREA 38
dialogues.text: Hendley arrives at one of the trucks, Snakes open a tool box, whisks out a small wrench and pliers. A Ferret spots him. Hendley quickly moves away. He is joined by Ashley-Pitt and Sandy MacDonald. He immediately switches the tools to MacDonald who hides them on his person while WERNER rushes up. Werner is a Ferret. While not stupid, neither is he overly bright. The demands on manpower in Germany pre- cluded elways having brains and efficiency at the level of a sry in a prison camp.

dialogues.speaker: WERNER
dialogues.text: You steal some tools from the truck?

dialogues.speaker: HENDLEY
dialogues.text: Tools?

dialogues.speaker: WERNER
dialogues.text: Why are you loafing here? Is there a law?

dialogues.speaker: VERNER
dialogues.text: Oh, American,

dialogues.speaker: HENDLEY
dialogues.text: Yes, and you are a German.

dialogues.speaker: WERNER
dialogues.text: Of course. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: “C) He immediately begins to search Hendley, patting him \ , all over. He speaks in his earnest way.

dialogues.speaker: WERNER
dialogues.text: (continuing) Why do you come to Germany? Why fight for England - your enemy?

dialogues.speaker: _ HENDLEY
dialogues.text: (keeping his attention) Enemy? What do you mean?

dialogues.speaker: WERNER
dialogues.text: In.1812 they burned your capitol. ‘HENDLEY What? Propaganda! Werner is through with him -- turns to MacDonald, but Ashley-Pitt places himself first and Werner begins Searching him.

dialogues.speaker: HENDLEY
dialogues.text: ” (continuing) —_ . Nothing but propaganda, thet's all. ' WERNER . (shaking his head; steadfastly reiterating) It's in the history books. I read it. As Werner searches Ashley-Pitt the latter laughs, can't stand to be searched, he's so ticklish.

dialogues.speaker: ASHLEY-PITT
dialogues.text: (putting. on an act) Oh, I-say. Please! I can't bear it. I'm very ticklish. Under ccver of this MacDonald siips tools to Hendley who gets them into his trousers rocket.

dialogues.speaker: WERNER
dialogues.text: (searching MacDonald) For stealing tools, cooler.

dialogues.speaker: HENDLEY
dialogues.text: What tools?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: bh

dialogues.speaker: WERNER
dialogues.text: Go now. Away from here. They wali: away.

dialogues.speaker: BY WARNING WIRE -. HILTS 39
dialogues.text: stands contemplating the. area between the wire and the fences, and their relation to the goon towers. He is oblivious to the uproar of the fight which is now diminishing. His preoccupied slapping of the baseball in his first baseman's mitt stops. GOFF, another American joins him.

dialogues.speaker: GOFF \
dialogues.text: ~ Only one other Yank in the place as far as I can find out. Seems like we're new boys. ‘ (beat) Hey, you in some kind of trance or something?

dialogues.speaker: HILTS
dialogues.text: We got us a blind spot.

dialogues.speaker: GOFF
dialogues.text: Huh?

dialogues.speaker: HILTS
dialogues.text: ‘The way those goon towérs are Placed, there's a blind spot on that fence.

dialogues.speaker: GOFF
dialogues.text: You're crazy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 39 4o il.

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: Hilts looks off intc nothing for some moments, his eyes glazing as he thinks. Then he snaps out of his reverie, nods his head briskly. First glancing about to see who is watching, he flips the baseball in the air a time or two, then pretending to fumble; deliberately shoves the ball to the place at the fence. No one notices this. Except Goff:

dialogues.speaker: GOFF -
dialogues.text: (appalled) You ain't going out there!

dialogues.speaker: HILTS
dialogues.text: Not till the Goons're looking somewhere else. AT RUSSIAN GROUP ‘ 40 Merivale taps a man in front of him.

dialogues.speaker: MERIVALE
dialogues.text: Tovarich. The man turns. Merivaie holds up two cigarettes, Pantomimes he will trade cigarettes for the axe the man is carrying, and the coat he is wearing. The exchange takes piace. A German guard suddenly shouts an order. Merivale stiffens, then as the men march off realizes that was the command. As the Russians move along the pass the far corner of a hut. Sedgwick pops from behind the corner, falls in behind Merivale. He too has messed himself up and with his gaunt face 41 looks perhaps more convincing than Merivale.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: as they march along.

dialogues.speaker: SEDGWICK
dialogues.text: (whispering) You know any Russian?

dialogues.speaker: MERIVALE
dialogues.text: Cniy one phrase.

dialogues.speaker: SEDGWICK
dialogues.text: Well, come on!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ya vass lublu.

dialogues.speaker: SEDGWICK
dialogues.text: Ya vass -- ? (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: MERIVALE
dialogues.text: Lublu,.

dialogues.speaker: SEDGWICK
dialogues.text: (practicing) Ya vass lublu. Ya vass lublu. (then) What's it mean?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I love you.

dialogues.speaker: SEDGWICK
dialogues.text: (reacts, then sourly) What good is that?

dialogues.speaker: MERIVALE
dialogues.text: I-couldn't say. Hadn't planned on using it myself.

dialogues.speaker: AT APPELL AREA
dialogues.text: all eyes are attracted to the marching Russians and the purp gun guards marching with them. Ramsey is entering the compound, stands near Hendley, watching.

dialogues.speaker: AT THE WARNING WIRE 43
dialogues.text: Hilts notices the attention paid to the marching Russians He takes a deep breath and; as Goff watches in. horror, steps over the warning wire, saunters out to the ball. At the fence he stands motionless for a moment. . The sentries are watching the Russians. It is apparent the goonbo: men don't see him, and he indicates this with a gesture to Goff. Then reaches down for his ball to start back. At this moment, the ferret, FRICK, spots him, yells. There is a burst of fire from a nearby. sentry, the bullets splattering around Hilts' feet as he dives out into the clear area between the warning wire and the fence.

dialogues.speaker: EILTS
dialogues.text: (yelling) Nicht shasen:! Don't shoot: Hold it: He holds his arms high above his head, rockstill. Every gun in sight is fined on Hilts though firing is held. Even the marching Russians and their guards halt as all watch. Frick runs to the edge of the warning wire, shouts at Hilts. (CONTINUED )

dialogues.speaker: FRICK
dialogues.text: You fool: To cross the wire is death.

dialogues.speaker: HILTS
dialogues.text: Huh?

dialogues.speaker: FRICK
dialogues.text: This wire. The warning wire. It 41s absolutely forbidden to cross it. You know that! Hilts holds up the basebell.

dialogues.speaker: . HILTS
dialogues.text: My baseball rolled over. How “else could I get it?

dialogues.speaker: / FRICK
dialogues.text: You first ask permission. Hilts turns to a goon box machine gunner, holds up the ball.

dialogues.speaker: HILTS
dialogues.text: Hey! Okay?

dialogues.speaker: . FRI
dialogues.text: (furious) Stop this nonsense and get over the wire or you will be killed - instantly.

dialogues.speaker: HILTS
dialogues.text: Okay - okay. The Russians are ordered on the march again. Goff stares at Hilts as if he has burst into flames.

dialogues.speaker: HILTS
dialogues.text: (slapping the ball, winks, studying the fence) Useful piece of information. 44 NEAR THE GATE - STRACHWITZ 4a watches the approaching Russians. As the guards open the main gate for the Russians and they are going through he calls out. Halt! STRACHWITZ t! (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ay 14. CONTINUED : 4a As the group is halted, Strachwitz walks over to them. Steps directly beside Sedgwick.

dialogues.speaker: . STRACHWITZ
dialogues.text: Step out? Merivale turns ‘to him,

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nyet. Nyet. (slapping Sedgwick on the shoulder) Tovarich! Tovarich!

dialogues.speaker: STRACHWITZ
dialogues.text: So?

dialogues.speaker: MERIVALE
dialogues.text: Tovarich:

dialogues.speaker: STRACHWITZ
dialogues.text: And vho vouches for you, Major Merivale? He gestures to the guards who move forward.

dialogues.speaker: STRACHVITZ
dialogues.text: Back in the camp. Next time you go to the cooler. : (to the guards) Bringzen die sofort ins't lage! As Merivale and Sedgwick are escorted back to the compoun the Russians are marched on out. Strachwitz takes a pitch fork from them. The trucks carrying the branches approach the gate. As the first truck stops at the gate Strachwits gets on to it, gently prods the branches. There is a Sudden yell. Strachwitz relaxes sardonically.

dialogues.speaker: IVES' VOICE
dialogues.text: Take it easy. He emerges from the branches.

dialogues.speaker: STRACHWITZ
dialogues.text: Your name?

dialogues.speaker: IVES
dialogues.text: (as he gets down) Flight Lt. Ives. (CONTINUED)
44 CONTINUED: (2) ay

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ( (nods as he remembers) Ah. yes. New.Zealander. The photograph in your file doesn't do you justice.

dialogues.speaker: STRACHWITZ
dialogues.text: (throws the pitch- fork to guard) Bringt jeden um den ihr findet. The guard begins to prod the branches savagely, making sure no one is there. Ives immediately gives a short - double whistie through his teeth which is a signal “the jig is up" end the others emerge from the. trucks somewha sheepishly. Then:

dialogues.speaker: STRACHWITZ
dialogues.text: I will take no action against you now. This is the first day here and there has been much stupidity - and carelessness. His eyes fall on Frick and the other ferrets near him, who shrivel. ia , STRACHWITZ oS (continuing) ! . on both sides. Dismiss. 45. aT TRUCK De , 45 during all of this, Hilts has sneaked to a truck, where he now hangs spread-eagled underneath by his hands and toes hooked into the lower chassis.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: turns away from Ives and the others as they exit and goes grimly to the truck under which Hilts is hanging. He orders the driver out with a gesture.and takes his place at the wheel. Then throwing the truck in reverse, backs into the camp, then slams it into gear and races into the tree trunk studded appell area. The others watch in horror as Strachwitz drives the truck across the stumps. Hilts flattens himself upward to his utmost as the stumps go by him by fractions of an inch. But he doesn't let go or ery out. Strachwitz stops the truck for a moment. Underneath the truck, Hilts' face is grim, but he doesn't budge. Strachwitz's face flushes with anger and slamming the truck in gear again he takes off, this time violently careening the truck over the highest stumps. Finally he stops; beaten in his attempt O to make Hilts give in. He gets out and stands by the tr

dialogues.speaker: PIGLET IVES 47
dialogues.text: He gives Strachwitz a loud derisive ‘bird'.

dialogues.speaker: STRACHWITZ
dialogues.text: reacts, n-ves Ives out of the corner of his eyes, but concentrates on the truck.

dialogues.speaker: STRACHVITZ
dialogues.text: You may come out now, Hilts! Hilts emerges and faces Strachwitz, his eyes cold with hatred as ferrets and guards converge. Hilts lifts up the tab of the collar of his shirt. Under it (as was often done by Americans in combat) is his insignia of rank.

dialogues.speaker: HILTS
dialogues.text: it's Captain Hilts.

dialogues.speaker: STRACHYWITZ
dialogues.text: (barking) Cooler! Hilts turms away, under guard, recovers his baseball mitt and bell from Goff and heads off toward the cooler. Strachwitz turns to Ives. Points at him.

dialogues.speaker: STRACHWITZ
dialogues.text: Cooler. . ‘Ives goes off after Hilts followed by two sentries. The others watch Strachwitz cautiously. Strachwitz looks them over balefully. Merivale, who has observed ali this with professional interest, moves to Goff.

dialogues.speaker: MERIVALE
dialogues.text: Who is that chap?

dialogues.speaker: GOFF
dialogues.text: Virgil Hilts, from Nebraska The Cooler King.

dialogues.speaker: MERIVALE
dialogues.text: I beg your pardon?

dialogues.speaker: GOFF
dialogues.text: (after a pause) In our last camp, Virgil logged more time in the cooler than all the rest put together.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: NEAR COOLER - HILTS AND IVES 4g march forward under guard into the cooler.”

dialogues.speaker: CORRIDOR
dialogues.text: Detention cells lead off the long corridor. Barred tiny door windows.

dialogues.speaker: CELL
dialogues.text: as he enters the tiny cement cell. The door slams shut. Footsteps, another cell door clangs shut as Ives too is put into solitary. Hilts jumps, catches his fingers-on the ledge of the high single small barred window, and chins himself up for a look. Then he drops to the floor again, where he paces about furiously. Finally to cool himself off, he stretches out on the floor where he methodically begins doing push-ups.

dialogues.speaker: MACDONALD 52
dialogues.text: Stands near a hut. With him are Danny, Willie, Ashley-Pit Merivale and Sedgwick. The Camp is quiet. Hendlev arrives, passes the tools he has stolen to Sedgwick.

dialogues.speaker: . HENDLEY '
dialogues.text: Add these to your collection. . _ MACDONALD . -  (aimost to himself) Quite a first twenty minutes, ZI must say.

dialogues.speaker: WILLIE
dialogues.text: I'd say we made fools of ourselves. -

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Danny, watching Strachwitz, speaks in his soft, intense , voice,

dialogues.speaker: DANNY
dialogues.text: As the Coerfeldwebel said, this is only the first day.

dialogues.speaker: HENDLEY
dialogues.text: He sure plans to separate the men from the boys.

dialogues.speaker: EXT, HEADQUARTERS
dialogues.text: A STASF CAR oe 53 approaches the Headquarters Building. KUHN, a high ranking Gestapo civilian gets out of the front seat. He is soft spoken, polite, dangerous. Two SS guards - Kuhn's constant body guard - get out of the back seat with a man in battered RAF uniform between them. This is SQUADRON LEADER CYRIL BARTLETT - a big blonde man with broad shoulders and cold intense eyes. He is handcuffed. Kuhn leads the way to the Headquarters Building.

dialogues.speaker: AT HUT 54
dialogues.text: MacDonald, Hendley and the others watch.

dialogues.speaker: MACDONALD
dialogues.text: (softly) Eric.

dialogues.speaker: ASHLEY-PITT
dialogues.text: Yes. I'll tell Ramsey. He exits. MacDonald speaks quitely to the other men.

dialogues.speaker: MACDONALD
dialogues.text: . Let's not tip who it is to the “goons. Pass the word. They move away in apparent disinterest.

dialogues.speaker: CAPTAIN POSEN
dialogues.text: comes out nervously to greet Kuhn.

dialogues.speaker: POSEN
dialogues.text: Guten morgen, Herr Kuhn. He exchanges salutes - also with the SS men - sees Bartlett, reacts.

dialogues.speaker: POSEN
dialogues.text: Er ist Bartlett, nicht wahr? Ich habe gehort das er...

dialogues.speaker: KUEN
dialogues.text: You might as well speak English. He understands German perfectiy. Where is Von Luger? (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: wn

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: With increasing nervousness, Posen leads the way. Obseqicusiy holds the door open for them. Bartiett is shoved into the building.

dialogues.speaker: RAMSEY 56
dialogues.text: tiredly puts his foot on a stool in the tiny room, studies great lists of typewritten names. There is Only one bunk in the room which would normally house four. - Rough furniture. Teapot and cup. An excited knock and Ashley-Pitt hurries in.

dialogues.speaker: ASHLEY-PITT
dialogues.text: (breathing hard from running) Excuse me, sir. Some of the chars think they spotted Cyril being taken into HQ.

dialogues.speaker: RAMSEY
dialogues.text: (then quickly) Better take precautions.

dialogues.speaker: ASHLEY-PITT
dialogues.text: Wheat? We have, sir.

dialogues.speaker: RAMSEY
dialogues.text: Bring him here. Soon as possible. —

dialogues.speaker: ASHLEY-PITT
dialogues.text: (exits) Yes sir.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The door opens without a imock and Kuhn enters with Bartlett and the SS officers, Posen bleakly behind.

dialogues.speaker: KUHN
dialogues.text: (saluting) Heil Hitler. Von Luger returns the salute but there is an edge to his manner and his distaste is thinly veiled. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: O
dialogues.text: Von iuger form. von Luger 20. 57

dialogues.speaker: KUHN
dialogues.text: (continuing; passing over papers The prisoner, Bartlett, is discharged into your custody, Coloriel von Luger. holds onto his temper, and signs the necessary KUHN . (puts down key to handcuffs on the desk) I suggest this prisoner be kept under the closest security confinement. Permanently.

dialogues.speaker: VON LUGER
dialogues.text: (to Posen, snaps) Make a note of Herr Kuhn's "suggestion". looks at the key. Posen unlocks the handcuffs.

dialogues.speaker: POSEN
dialogues.text: Ja, Herr Colonel.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (softly) ‘We have reason to believe he : . is the leader of numerous criminal escape attempts.

dialogues.speaker: VON LUGER
dialogues.text: (after pause) Squadron Leader Bartlett has been...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (refers to file) | ++. three months in your care “| and the Gestapo has only : | "peason to believe"?

dialogues.speaker: KUHN
dialogues.text: (gently) if he falls into our hands once more, he will not be s0 Tucky.

dialogues.speaker: VON LUGER
dialogues.text: hard) Escaped Air Force officers are the responsibility. of the Luftwaffe, not the Gestapo. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: KUHN
dialogues.text: At present, yes, Herr Colonel. That is why he is returned to your care. A silence, then in dismassal, Von Luger nods to Posen. ‘VON LUGER Put him in the camp. Bartlett and Posen and a guard exit. Kuhn's two SS men remain.

dialogues.speaker: KUEN
dialogues.text: (soft smile) Of course, if the Luftwaffe is not up to the task they wiil find themselves totally in our charge. We, regretfully, are not so professionally understanding. (gets ur) Heil Hitler: (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CONTINULD
dialogues.text: He exits. Von Luger stares after him. ‘ DISSOLVE TO:

dialogues.speaker: MAIN GATE
dialogues.text: Among them, Danny, Ashley-Pitt... :

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bartlett wearily approaches under heavy guard. Strachwitz watches.

dialogues.speaker: THE GROUP 60
dialogues.text: makes no reaction. Some turn away. Some watch casually. As Bartlett approaches closer Ashley-Pitt reacts to his gauntness. He comes through the gate, Ashley-Pitt wanders up.

dialogues.speaker: ASHLEY-PITT
dialogues.text: (casually) Hello, Cyril. You'll be in 104 - I'll show you. “BARTLETT (as casually) Thanks. : : They exit. Strachwitz stares after them...

dialogues.speaker: RAMSEY 61
dialogues.text: waits anxiously. A imock.

dialogues.speaker: RAMSEY
dialogues.text: Come in. Bartlett enters, Ashley-Pitt smiles - leaves the two men alone.

dialogues.speaker: BARTLETT
dialogues.text: Hello, sir.

dialogues.speaker: RAMSEY
dialogues.text: Hello, Cyril. (CONTINUED )

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: O) Between them there is enormous camarderie, enormous NO respect. But held right down.

dialogues.speaker: RAMSEY
dialogues.text: Looks like you've had a rough time.

dialogues.speaker: BARTLETT
dialogues.text: The Gestapo wanted to find out who helped me to the border. God! I had only a hundred yards to go.

dialogues.speaker: RAMSEY
dialogues.text: _ (after pause) The fellows wanted to put up a welcome committee, That's for later. Lot of your old. friends here,

dialogues.speaker: BARTLETT
dialogues.text: (hardly listening) Ch? Who?

dialogues.speaker: RAMSEY
dialogues.text: Danny Velinski... Willy Dix... ofS Ashley-Pitt... the Artful Dodger... oS . BARTLETT - : Old Merivale? Hasn't he made it yet? / :

dialogues.speaker: RAMSEY
dialogues.text: Not yet.

dialogues.speaker: BARTLETT
dialogues.text: i (locks around the camp) How long have you been here? a . . RAMSEY Arrived today. New camp. Expert guards. The elite. He turns back to the teapot, pours. From time to time he glances perturbed at Bartlett who sits staring into space lost in thought.

dialogues.speaker: RAMSEY
dialogues.text: Here. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: BARTLETT
dialogues.text: (drinking) My God, that's good. That's so good. (beat) Christ! We'll never get out of these bloody. camps.

dialogues.speaker: RAMSEY
dialogues.text: (after pause) Last of the tea until the Red Cross packages get through again. I scrounged this from Sedgwick.

dialogues.speaker: BARTLETT
dialogues.text: Is he here too?

dialogues.speaker: RAMSEY -
dialogues.text: (laughs } All the "rotten" eggs as Von Luger called us. (beat) They've cleaned out ali the camps and cumped us here. Bartlett stares at him suddenly alert. Ramsey is concerne a What's the matter?

dialogues.speaker: BARTLETT
dialogues.text: (after pause) What about Tommy Bristol?

dialogues.speaker: RAMSEY
dialogues.text: No. He's not here yet. But there's an American called Hendley. He's supposed to be twice as good a thief and blackmailer as... (beat) Vhy?

dialogues.speaker: BARTLETT
dialogues.text: Don't you see? Unknowingly the goons have put together the finest escape team in history. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: RAMSEY
dialogues.text: They know what they're doing, Cyril. Have you seen the double wires? The towers? Triple guards? Tunnelling's out - the soil‘s too sandy. They've thought of everything. They've even Strachwitz in charge of the ferrets.

dialogues.speaker: BARTLETT
dialogues.text: Isaw him. He's very efficient. (beat) I'm calling a meeting of "x" immediately.

dialogues.speaker: RAMSEY
dialogues.text: (thoughtfully) I think you should stay out of it, Cyril. You're a marked man.

dialogues.speaker: CYRIL
dialogues.text: I was elected "Big X". It's my job.

dialogues.speaker: RAMSEY
dialogues.text: I mow. And you're the best shat's ever been. But I think it's time for a change.

dialogues.speaker: BARTLETT
dialogues.text: (beat) Do you think I'm wire happy?

dialogues.speaker: RAMSEY
dialogues.text: I think it would be a good thing for you to slack off. There's plenty of time.

dialogues.speaker: BARTLETT
dialogues.text: Not for me. (pause) I've an idea that the whole bloody Reich is going to regret the day they built this camp. RAMSEY . I must point out, Cyril, that however unsatisfactory this camp is - or will be - we are still in the hands of the Luftwaffe - not the Gestapo. (MORE ) (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: . RAMSEY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: (crisply) The "X" organization was formed to assist escapes - by team effort - not to wage @ private war.

dialogues.speaker: BARTLETT
dialogues.text: I want to fight the war, sir. The way I know best. I'm not wire happy. Yet. When I am, I'll tell you. You can trust me, sir. A long vause,

dialogues.speaker: RAMSEY
dialogues.text: All right.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ramsey, Merivale, Danny, Willie, MacDonald, Ashley-Pitt, Sedgwick, Griffiths, Cavendish, and Hendley and Bartlett.

dialogues.speaker: BARTLETT
dialogues.text: (getting up - smiles) . Well, sir, I think we're all . interested in Von Luger's "policy". i think we should follow his instructions carefully. : (to the others) Yetre going to devote our energies to gardening, sports, cultural pursuits. We put the : goons to sleep. Meantthile "Xx" mo goes into operation immediately. (begins pacing) We are going to make some changes -- particularly in pelicy. As and from today there are going to be no more blitz-out, no lone man operations. They've locked us up in a special prison - so we're going to have a special plan. A big one. (pause) We're going to tunnel... (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: DANNY
dialogues.text: No good, Cyril. Swil's too sandy.

dialogues.speaker: BARTLETT
dialogues.text: We'll sink a shaft thirty feet deep, then tunnel out horizontally. Theat should get us under the sand, avoid the goon probing, and avoid sound detectors. (deat) The first tunnel will go out of ' Hut 105, directly east, under the wire and under the cooler to the safety of the trees. There is a silence. Then:

dialogues.speaker: WILLIE
dialogues.text: But that's over three hundred feet.

dialogues.speaker: BARTLETT
dialogues.text: (calmly to Cavendish) What's the actual figure, Dennis?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Three hundred and thirty-five ‘feet. . a:

dialogues.speaker: WILLIE
dialogues.text: after pause) You said "first tunnel", Cyril?

dialogues.speaker: BARTLETT
dialogues.text: Yes. The second goes north from somewhere in here, and - . the third goes south out of 104. : ba (beat) Code names, Tom, Dick and Harry. They all stare at him as though he is crazy. The door opens and Blythe comes in.

dialogues.speaker: BLYTHE
dialogues.text: Sorry I'm late.

dialogues.speaker: BARTLETT
dialogues.text: That's all right, Colin. We're going to tunnel.

dialogues.speaker: O BLYTHE
dialogues.text: Good. . (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: MACDONALD
dialogues.text: (to Bartlett) Thet's quite an undertaking.

dialogues.speaker: BARTLETT
dialogues.text: I propose we involve the whole camp in some way or another. You'll be in charge of security. You'll have to devise the best security net ever.

dialogues.speaker: MACDONALD
dialogues.text: I-can imagine.

dialogues.speaker: ASHLEY-PITT
dialogues.text: But where the hell are we going to hide the dirt? That's going to amount to about thirty tons.

dialogues.speaker: BARTLETT
dialogues.text: I'd say it was nearer forty. . You're the dirt disposal expert, come up with an answer.

dialogues.speaker: SEDGWICK
dialogues.text: (after pause - hesitantly) Why three tunnels ‘Sir, all at. once.

dialogues.speaker: BARTLETT
dialogues.text: Because we're ready for a really big job. And if they find one tunnel then we've still two spare. We're still organized. They look at each other, then once more MacDonald breaks the silence. .

dialogues.speaker: MACDONALD
dialogues.text: How many men do you plan to take out?

dialogues.speaker: BARTLETT
dialogues.text: Two hundred and fifty. They Stare at him, knowing that he's crazy. Bartlett starts talking - his magnetism shows. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.text: : It sounds impossible, doesn't it? But I imow we can do it. It only sounds impossible. Two years ago it would have been impossible. But now, now we're experts. Now we've got the skill. (beat) And think - think what a smack in the bloody teeth it would be for the goons. Hitler would have a bioody heart attack - this is their Number One security prison - that'd make a few heads fall. And think of the foul up -— the monumental foul up we'd cause them. There is a dead silence. They look at each other, imesmer ized. Then, Bartlett turns to Griffiths.

dialogues.speaker: BARTLETT
dialogues.text: You're head tailor. We'll need over a hundred suits of clothes. wo (to Cavendish) o~* Two hundred end fifty maps. . - (to Sedgwick) You're head of manufacturing. _ Two hundred and fifty compasses. ‘and iron rations for four days. (to MacDonald) You're responsible for security. I've got to have a system of stooges covering the whole compound from front. to back, covering every goon in and out, and a signal System so perfect that if a ferret - gets within a hundred feet of a hut : : where work is going on, we can close down without a sign. (to Hendley) You're chief scrounger. You've got to get the material. Whatever it is. And your team is also responsible for blackmailing operations - I've got to have local train timetables, map information, etc. (MORE )

dialogues.speaker: BARTLETT, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: (to Danny) Danny, you'll be in charge of traps and second to Willie who is as usual the Tunnel King. You have to have your traps planned and ready for digging operations ain two weeks. We'll pick locations tomorrow. . (he hesitates, then smiles - to all of them) Two hundred and fifty of us are going to break out of here before winter. In dead silence:

dialogues.text: Hendley c-mes down the corridor thoughtfully, turns into:

dialogues.speaker: HENDLEY'S ROOM .- HENDLEY . 64
dialogues.text: enters. There are two bunks, table, chairs. He notices with surprise that there is someone.else's gear on the upper tun. He frowns at it. The door opens and Colin Blythe s:ters. He‘carries ea hot teapot. .

dialogues.speaker: BLYTHE
dialogues.text: Oh, hello, Hendley - I'm Colin Blythe. They put me in here thinking you might be able to help me with my work.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He puts the teapot down, ostentatiously puts on its tea cozy, and begins meticulously to straighten his meager possessions. Hendley reacts as he sees binoculars. He picks them up, glances through them out of the window.

dialogues.speaker: BLYTHE
dialogues.text: For birds.

dialogues.speaker: HENDLEY
dialogues.text: Ido a little hunting myself.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ‘Not. hunting. Watching. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: / 64 CONTINUED
dialogues.text: /O. Hendley puts down the glasses, re-studies Blythe. .

dialogues.speaker: HENDLEY
dialogues.text: Oh. A. bird watcher?

dialogues.speaker: BLYTHE
dialogues.text: Yes. Watching them and drawing them. Are there bird watchers in the States? (beat) I suppose not. (beat) Fea?

dialogues.speaker: HENDLEY
dialogues.text: I only drank tea once - in @ hospital. Blythe rcoises his eyebrows slightly, then busies himself pourin; 4 cup of tea.

dialogues.speaker: BLYTHE,
dialogues.text: I'll need a camera.

dialogues.speaker: HENDLEY
dialogues.text: a (mock amazement) OD . Only one?

dialogues.speaker: BLYTHE
dialogues.text: One should do if it's a good ~ one. A thirty-five millimeter f£2.8 single lens reflex with a focal plane shutter should suffice.

dialogues.speaker: HENDLEY
dialogues.text: (after a moment) I'll see what I can do.

dialogues.speaker: BLYTHE
dialogues.text: And film, of course.

dialogues.speaker: HENDLEY
dialogues.text: Oh, of course. Blythe pours the tea, observes its weak color,

dialogues.speaker: BLYTHE
dialogues.text: I'm afraid I've used these’ poor ‘leaves close to twenty times. (tastes - shakes Co his head) CO But it's nev that I mind so much. Tea without milk is so uncivilized. (CONTINUED )

dialogues.speaker: BLYTHE
dialogues.text: I couldn't have been more surprised if you'd produced Churchill.

dialogues.speaker: HENDLEY
dialogues.text: You want him? :

dialogues.speaker: BLYTHE
dialogues.text: (looks at Hendley, amazed) Of course not.

dialogues.speaker: DANNY
dialogues.text: I've got to have a bag of cement.

dialogues.speaker: HENDLEY
dialogues.text: (wearily) Only one?

dialogues.speaker: DANNY
dialogues.text: Three would be better. ‘Night. The door cleses as softly as it opened.

dialogues.speaker: HENDLEY
dialogues.text: Blythe - what are you doing here?

dialogues.speaker: BLYTHE
dialogues.text: Don't really know. It was my own silly fault. I'm in photographic interpretation. Went.for a joy ride to see for. myself. Terrifying. The aircraft bought it. Got shot down. Very poor show.

dialogues.speaker: HENDLEY
dialogues.text: No, I meant, what do you do here? .

dialogues.speaker: BLYTHE
dialogues.text: Oh, I'm the forger. Blythe sips his tea with great satisfaction.

dialogues.speaker: BLYTHE
dialogues.text: Splendid!

64 Hendley opens his foct locker, produces a small can of condensed milk. Blythe takes it. Blythe poises the cup at his lips with great anticipation There is a surreptitious knock. Danny comes in. Hendley stares

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The long beams from the searchlights on the goon tovers sweep the darkened compound and huts as the Hundfuehrers prowl with their dogs.

dialogues.speaker: THE WHOLE CAMP
dialogues.text: In ranks, being counted by ferrets under Strachwitz. Samsey is in front of the ranks - Posen nearby. The final man is counted. Strachwitz takes the tally to Fosen who nods.

dialogues.speaker: POSEN
dialogues.text: (to Ramsey) Dismiss!

dialogues.speaker: RAMSEY
dialogues.text: Dismiss: The men stream away to begin the new day.

dialogues.speaker: A DETAIL
dialogues.text: begins drawing gardening: tools. Danriy and Hendley are watching. :

dialogues.speaker: DANNY
dialogues.text: (sourly) I could certainly use one of those.

dialogues.speaker: HENDLEY
dialogues.text: (slight smile) Now you know the rules, Danny. Gardening tools are only for gardening. (peat) Relax. Use what you've got. Merivale comes up.

dialogues.speaker: MERIVALE
dialogues.text: You're toth wanted in 105.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (wearily) No peace for the Godly. They exit.

dialogues.speaker: NEAR THE FRONT HUU'S
dialogues.text: take up var-.ous positions strategically chosen so that they can see one another. Hendley and Danny cross to 105 as: :

dialogues.speaker: NEAR THE FRONT GATE
dialogues.text: the duty "pilot" establishes himself where he can watch headquarters, and another duty stooge sits down by a smal incinerztor next to which there is a coal scuttle and an old Rel Cross box. He is in-clear view of the man near the gate as well as the others around the huts. The man at the gate looks the whole headquarters area over care- fully, then surreptitiously signals the man at the incin- erator who places the Red Cross box to the left of the incinerator and leans the coal scuttle against it. This Signal is relayed to a man sitting at Hut 105, He pulls a string beside him that leads into the hut.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: enter to join Bartlett, Ashley-Pitt (the lookout at the window), and a few others. The small tin can filled with pecsles, hanging om a string, rattles the "all clear". Then Danny moves the stove away from its tiled base. He carefully lifts the base - which now is fitted to a camoufleging hinged frame - reveals the foundations made out of cemented broken rubble. ©

dialogues.speaker: . BARTLETT
dialogues.text: Pretty good so far.

dialogues.speaker: DANNY
dialogues.text: We'll keep a fire in the stove so the goons won't feel inclined to move it. (beat) I'll have to have some new tiles. A couple are chipped’ -- we can't take chances.

dialogues.speaker: HENDLEY
dialogues.text: (immediately) There're scne in one thirteen's wash room that'd match perfectly.

dialogues.speaker: BARTLETT
dialogues.text: (he indicates foundation to Danny) That's rather awkward. Good. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: DANNY
dialogues.text: (grins) Not when you're organized. Suddenly from outside comes the SOUND of hammering, clattering. Bartlett reacts; goes over to the window. EXT. HuT 105 - DAY

dialogues.speaker: DIVERSIONARY HOBBY MAKERS 71
dialogues.text: are grouped around the hut, beating cans end plates into alternate shapes, come decorous, mostly useless. A ferret passes irritatecly, then leaves...

dialogues.speaker: SITTING RCOM
dialogues.text: takes cut a piece of chalk, writes 73 cn the undersice of the traz, stares down. Over the hubbub from outside, grinly:

dialogues.speaker: DANNY
dialogues.text: Now, you Black Beast! This time I'm going to do you. Once and for all. He takes the crude pickaxe adapted from a baseball bat and a steel spike, and starts hacking at the cemented ‘foundation. After pause, Hendley turns to Bartlett:

dialogues.speaker: HENDLEY
dialogues.text: (quietly) Why seventy-three?

dialogues.speaker: BARTLETT
dialogues.text: This is the seventy-third - tunnel Danny's started. :

dialogues.speaker: HENDLEY
dialogues.text: How many got discovered?

dialogues.speaker: BARTLETT
dialogues.text: Well, this one hasn't yet.

dialogues.speaker: HENDLEY
dialogues.text: : (quickly) Touch wood!

dialogues.speaker: CORRIDOR " , 73
dialogues.text: The ‘CAMERA SHOOTS DOWN the length of the narrow corridor towards the entrance door at the far end, raking along the doors.to the individual celis. The guards enter the door in the background with food pails.

dialogues.speaker: 1ST GUARD
dialogues.text: (with phoney joviality) Guten morgen, Frustuk. pause } Breakfast: There is no response from the cells. The first guard opens the lower trap and the second puts a pail through it. Then the two come dovm to the foreground ceil, pass the second pail through its trap door. Without further word they march off towards the entrance door.

dialogues.speaker: IN CELL
dialogues.text: raises tiie lid of his pail and studies the contents with revulsicn. The entrance door is heard clanging shut. Ives squnts down at the lower trapdoor, and reaches out through it with his pail. '

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: the pail is tipped over and. the contents dumped out. As they gurgle down into the drain, a pail emerges from the- far cell and its contents are dumped out.

dialogues.speaker: IN IVES' CELL
dialogues.text: paces restlessly. Over comes a strange SOUND. A mad- dening, constant plin-plank-plonk-smack. Ives looks at the wall in exasperation, controls himself, resumes his 7 pacing. : IN HILTS' CELL - HILTS “7 is sitting on the floor of the concrete walled cubicle playing a complicated game of rebound with his ball and glove. He is extremely skillful with the various ricochets, which set up a reguiar rhythm. (INTERCUT - IVES - HILTS. They have to shout to be heard.

dialogues.text: Hilts: (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ‘OO

dialogues.speaker: HILTS
dialogues.text: Yeah.

dialogues.speaker: IVES
dialogues.text: (making conversation) What did you do in the States? Play basebali?

dialogues.speaker: HILTS
dialogues.text: Nope. Went to college. Did do a little motorcycle riding.

dialogues.speaker: IVES
dialogues.text: (interest) Professional?

dialogues.speaker: MACDONALD

(with gestures) First we dig straight down three feet - spread the dirt around so it won't make a pile = then go straight out. Bartlett breaks the reverie. - BARTLETT  . When do you intend to try this?

dialogues.speaker: IN THE HUT
dialogues.text: in the window, relax.

They are in a bad way; sweating and breathing in gasps. Ives scoops wearily with saucepan, passes the dirt back to Hilts. Hilts makes an attempt to put the dirt behind him, can't. He-sags wearily.

We're boxed in. IvES what?

The CAMERA MOVES. to follow his look. Hilts is folded up like a jackknife with his. kmees up under his chin against his chest. He is completely surrounded with dirt which has closed in behind him. Ives takes some time to grasp what has happened, then:

dialogues.speaker: HILTS

HRILTS' CELL - HILTS 123 i hurls himself to the floor, begins grimly doing push-ups to work off the violence of his disappointment.

Suddenly Werner stares appalled. The can ef Danish butter. Shakily he picks it up. The can 4s stamped in German, "Officer: Mess Only".

dialogues.speaker: WERNER
dialogues.text: (appalled) Von Luger's butter, Gott in Himmel! Ich bin ferucht!

dialogues.speaker: HENDLEY
dialogues.text: Help yourself. You went the . . can?

dialogues.speaker: WERNER
dialogues.text: Gott in Himmel, nein!

dialogues.speaker: HENDLEY
dialogues.text: Why not? We're friends.

dialogues.speaker: WERNER
dialogues.text: With you in the cooler, will we still be friends? I mst report it. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ss

(puts can down) I don’t understand you, Werner. Report what? That you and I chatted in my room? Werner stares at him ~ starts out - remembers the chocola Takes it out and tries to give it back. Hendley stuffs it back in Werner's pocket, holds him from going.

dialogues.speaker: HENDLEY
dialogues.text: What difference does a little _ chocolate make? It isn't half as much as you took when you cleaned out France.

dialogues.speaker: WERNER
dialogues.text: No! No! Hendley suddenly gives up. -

dialogues.speaker: HENDLEY
dialogues.text: Oh, all right, Werner. If you don't want it - forget it.

dialogues.speaker: WERNER

dialogues.speaker: BLYTHE

dialogues.text: You certainly have! Look? (Sad ny examines it

dialogues.speaker: . BLYTHE

As the lecture continues, Hendley enters through another door, stops as he spots Kramer. BLYTHE (continuing) Sit down, Hendley. You'll find sketching materials on one of the tables. (continues to lecture) Observe carefully how long they are - here - in comparison with the wingset of the common purple heron. Hendley heads for the cnly available seat. Near the door.

Blythe continues his lecture for a few seconds, then two sharp raps on the window are heard. Blythe immediately drops his lecture and crosses to Bartlett. The men in-the room put aside their pretense of bird study and get out their real wor!

dialogues.speaker: BLYTHE

During this Blythe studies the documents hungrily, myopically holds the papers bare inches from his eyes. This isn't noticed by Bartlett. or MacDonald who are looking at Hendley.

dialogues.speaker: BLYTHE

dialogues.text: is. covered with grime. With MacDonald, Ashley-Pitt ' looks off irritatedly...

dialogues.speaker: ASHLEY- PITT

dialogues.speaker: BARTLETT 165
dialogues.text: as he moves over to join Hilts. ‘

dialogues.speaker: BARTLETT
dialogues.text: . (casually) .° . I thought by this time you and Ives would be over the hill and into the wild blue yonder. What went wrong?

dialogues.text: There's a verse in | Ecclesiasticus - "There is one that laboureth and taketh pains, and maketh haste, and is 80 much the more behind". Hilts smiles faintly. BARTLETT (continuing) The Bible also says: “Take counsel with thine enemies, make them thy friends.”

Beware of a counsellor and know before what need he hath, lest he counsel for himself and cast his lot upon thee. And -- uh -- clobber thee." (grins) That's Ecclesiasticus, too. (laughs ) I didn't finish my quote. It goes -- “Take counsel with thine enemies, make them thy friends. For the common good."

dialogues.speaker: HILTS
dialogues.text: What have you got in mind? (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: OC

dialogues.speaker: HILTS

dialogues.speaker: 165A WERNER

dialogues.speaker: HENDLEY 166
dialogues.text: has just come into the room. Is brushing off his “ clothes. Blythe is lying in his bunk. The door bursts «~ open, and Werner rushes in. Distraught. (CONTINUED )

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: He stops

dialogues.speaker: WERNER
dialogues.text: Herr Hendley, I -- as he sees Blythe. (affably) Hello, Werner. Oh, Biythe's a friend, too. (looks Werner over) What's the matter?

dialogues.text: I've looked every place.” Eve’ place. I must have lost them -- (lowers his voice) © -- while I was in here.

dialogues.speaker: WERNER .

dialogues.text: © : HENDLEY (checks him) Might look a little peculiar for you and me to be probing around this time of night. Leave it to me,

He is accompanied by Posen and Strachwitz who carries a clipboard, and is followed by four security guards who have been waiting. The gates swing open. The stooge system relays warning. Sorren is the "Luty Pilot". INT, HUT 105 ~ Day THE TIN can 177 rattles. Moving like lightening, Willie, Danny and other digsers pour out of the shaft, slap the scnd off thir longjohns and, as the trap is closed, jump into their regular clothing like firemen. Von Luger and his entourage approach studiously ignoring their presence, move past them. Von Luger stops, looks off at a tower guard. There is something about the condition of his machine gun.

dialogues.speaker: VON LUGER
dialogues.text: (to Posen) Hauptmann Posen, die wache nat den minutionstrtel nicht im machinengewehr.

dialogues.speaker: POSEN
dialogues.text: (calls to man) Minutionstirtel nicht im machinengewehr!! As the tower guard complies, Posen speaks to Strachwitz. POSEN (continuing) . Was sie den namen? .

dialogues.text: Klausner. Strachwitz makes a note on his clipboard as Von Luger furns toward the gardeners, some of whom have paused Oo watch.

dialogues.speaker: VON LUGER
dialogues.text: Please, gentlemen. Continue. This is merely a routine insepetion. Turning to Ramsey, who is right next to him, he speaks as if he had just seen him. There is a Subtie difference in Von Luger's manner. Although he is cooly polite there seems to be an ambiguous tone to all he says. VON LUGER (continuing) I must say I am surprised with all this activity, Group Captain. Pleased, of course, but surprised. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: RAMSEY
dialogues.text: Surprised, Colonel?

dialogues.speaker: VON LUGER
dialogues.text: Fliers are gentlemen, not peasants to dig in the earth. So I am surprised.

dialogues.speaker: RAMSEY
dialogues.text: Tne English are very keen on gardening.

dialogues.speaker: VON LUGER
dialogues.text: (after a look at Hilts) Yes. But...flowers. Is it not so?

dialogues.speaker: RAMSEY
dialogues.text: But you can't eat flower: Sy Colonel. Von Luger's face is impassive. There is a long beat.

dialogues.speaker: VON LUGER
dialogues.text: A good point. . Another beat then begins to exit. He stops near Hilts. VON LUGER ( contdnuing) Fresh soil, Hilts?

dialogues.speaker: HILTS

dialogues.text: as Ramsey casually returns to working the ground. Ashley-Pitt stares off after Von Luger.

dialogues.text: (under his breath) j My word. . (CONTINUED )

dialogues.text: Er, beg your pardon sir?

Von Luger smiles, glances at the list of his guards and ferrets - the times of ~ entry, times of departure. He glances at his watch, enters his own name under "out" and the time, hands the list back. Pleasantly: VON LUGER (continuing) Give my compliments to Group Captain Ramsey. Ask him if I could have a daily copy. It - would be most useful to have an : independent - trustworthy - report on the movements of my men. Nods rolitely, moves the Red cross box into the all clear position, exits. In his nervousness, Sorren almost salutes his eye out.

dialogues.text: THE TRAP DOOR OF "Tom" 182 is open. Sedgwick is passing down some sections of bedboards and other wood.

(to the tunnel) Come on, you Black Beast, behave! No more falls, no nothing. Danny's your friend. He scrapes the sand into the trolley, mumbling all the time, laboriously starts crewing.» back as Ives hauls the trolley. woe . : . , AD THE BASE OP THE SHAFT - IVES “185 empties the trolley, Hilts helping, into the growing Pile of sand. Hilts calls down the tunnel to Danny.

dialogues.speaker: . DANNY'S VOICE

dialogues.text: Coming up! Ives. turns away to clean away the sand. There is a sudde sharp crack. Ives and Hilts look up, startled. They see the shaft shoring boards tremble nervously, then they twist out of place. Sand begins cascading...more boards begin to buckle.

The sand begins to drown him - the whole shaft collapsing. Ives and Hilts turn and drag Danny out just as the sand is sucking him to certain death.

A shallow _tray.on wheels on wooden railway-lines trundles backward - as Ives jerks the signal rope. Hilts stops for a moment stares at the new dirt.

dialogues.speaker: HILTS
dialogues.text: All that'd get you is a bottom full of dog fangs. The door opens, Ashley-Pitt enters carrying a blanket.

dialogues.speaker: BARTLETT
dialogues.text: Where the devil've you been?

dialogues.speaker: ASHLEY-PITT
dialogues.text: (with great dignity) Not sitting on my bottom! I'm Royal Navy. (deat) Now you promise not to laugh?

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: They stare at him blankly.

dialogues.speaker: BARTLETT
dialogues.text: Why should we laugh? Ashley-Pitt lays down a blanket, steps onto it, then, almost shyly, undoes his pants, steps out of them. Down each leg is a long thin cylindrical bag with a string attached to the bottom of each. Like a magician performin his magnus opus, he pulls the strings with a flourish and dirt cascades out of the bottoms on to the blanket. They all roar with laughter.

dialogues.speaker: BARTLETT
dialogues.text: Ashley-Pitt, you, sir, have just become immortal!

Hilts is drilling a group of moth-eaten POW's. 215 CLOSE SHOT - THEIR FEET noe 215_ Yellow sand streams from pants legs in the central sectio of marchers. Following feet scuff the sand into the dirt. And now the feet have passed... the compound dirt is es i always was... .

dialogues.text: are joined by other "full-dirt carriers" and the "empty- dirt carriers" judiciously depart for further supplies. - Beyond them is a volley ball match. Cheers. .

dialogues.text: GERMAN: Four. HILTS: That's average. I've got a motorcycle at home. GERMAN: So? EILTS: (points at the Stars and Stripes) Across the ocean in America.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown

dialogues.speaker: Unknown

dialogues.speaker: Unknown

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: HILTS: (snorts) That's pretty sad. GERMAN: (bristling) How fast does yours go? HIZTS: (with fingers) A hundred. — GERMAN: Ridiculous.. Big mouth American! HILTS: (with. Heil Hitler salute and holding his nose) German stuff stinks. GERMAN: Up yours. HILTS: Up yours. .

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: is strangely quiet after the roistering tumult, which inside the hut is muted. Strachwitz is near the stove. He looks around angrily. Kramer comes from the shower area.

dialogues.text: (whispers ) Garnichts.

dialogues.text: “THE SINGERS . 281 are almost completely crocked. Sedgwick plonks away. Milling mass of people. Merivale, half crocked now, suddeniy lifts up his arms, waist high and calls out:

Immediately two POW's get either side of him as instantly an opposing “serum formation" gets together and the two sides lock, Merivale the "hooker" on one side, MacDonald the other. Miraculously a rugger ball appears and the scrum half tosses the ball into the writhing mass of struggling bodies.

dialogues.speaker: SEDGWICK 282
dialogues.text: turns and watches in a drunken stupor. Hilts enters and heads for the pianc. He stares into its guts. Then, as Sedgwick is momentarily distracted, Hilts whips out a pair of wire cutters, cuts some of the piano wire strings wraps them up and walks away contentedly...

dialogues.speaker: THE SCRUM DOWN 283
dialogues.text: a packed jammed mass of shouting, laughing, fighting men.

dialogues.text: crawls from under the swirling mass and heads tiredly for a chair. Sits. Now we see he has the ball in his lap. He smiles seraphically as over comes shouts:

dialogues.speaker: VOICES
dialogues.text: Here... I've got it... Come on «+. Heel... heel, chaps. It's over here, come on shove, shove... heel, heel... 285 again. When he

dialogues.speaker: SEDGWICK
dialogues.text: turns back from the melee, starts playing gets to the upper register, "plunk plunk", there is only a dull "thud thud". He frowns, tries it again. The same. He shrugs, continues playing - always including the "thud thud"...

dialogues.speaker: HENDLEY'S GROUP
dialogues.text: heads toward the fire pool, Bartlett and Ramsey watch 286 amused. Rather than change course, Hendley leads the column into it. The shaliow end... deeper... deeper... deeper... then they all scramble out. Now a body remains in the water, floats face down...

dialogues.text: Gost to be a limey... obvioush... eun never hole thre tiddly. No one mikes an attempt to pull the man out. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.text: (slurring) Dishgusting... dishgrash (hick) t'the flag... jusht lecshs faith... He weaves ever and picks up a blanket someone has dropped and drapes it over his shoulders, staggers to the edge of the pool. Like a prophet, he raises his arms over the water. : . :

This; too, disappears. Frantically he rushes for Strachwitz. Whispered conversation. Strachwitz and Kramer carefully move the stove off the hase plate. dialogues.text: appalled... :

Ramsey stands alone in front of the ranks. Von Luger a few paces away, Staring at the ranks. Kuhn and. SS guards are there. The only movement is Kuhn ambling along the front rank... LINES OF POW FACES 31¢ taut with misery.

dialogues.text: gil staring off. Depressed. Rain trickles down their aces...

dialogues.speaker: , ENGINEER

dialogues.speaker: KUHN 319
dialogues.text: a deadly smile on his face. He stops in front of Hendley. «KUEN (almost gentiy) Ah, the American, Hendley, isn't it? What do you know of this? (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: Hendley stares at him. Kuhn half-smiles, moves on, stops again. . KUHN (continuing) MacDonald. Ah yes. Three escapes from Stalag Zwei. The "Security" expert. You almost fooled the Luftwaffe this time. (beat) We would not be so easy to fool. He moves on again. Stops in front of Danny, bypasses Hilts without a second glance. Softly: KUHN (continuing) Velinski. Why are you in. RAF uniform? A traitor, eh? Why aren't you with the rest of the Polish cowards in Warsaw.

dialogues.speaker: DANNY 320
dialogues.text: beside himself with rage. Almost on the verge of an insane attack. The SS guards have their hands on their holstered guns. Only a touch from Willie keeps Danny from gcing beserk. Kuhn strolls on, passes Ives, passes many FOW's. He is looking at Bartlett. . KUHN (continuing) ° Ah, Bartlett. What do you imow about this? Nothing, of course. The tunnel grew itself. of course. But there are ways to find the truth. If it is really important. Bartlett stares back at him, cold, beside himself with frustrated rage. VON LUGER ‘ 321 is joined by Strachwitz who salute smartly.

dialogues.speaker: STRACHWITZ
dialogues.text: (in German) Ready, sir. Von Luger nods, still looking off screen, almost complete covering his disgust of Kuhn.  322 323 324 325 326 327 328 329

dialogues.speaker: GERMAN ENGINEER 322
dialogues.text: is finishing attaching the wires to a detonation device. Then he snaps the handie up, stares off screen...

dialogues.speaker: KUHN 323
dialogues.text: stops in front of Ramsey.

dialogues.speaker: KUHN
dialogues.text: You are responsibie. . You know that? Ramsey stares at Kuhn stonily. Behind Kuhn, Von Luger approaches.

dialogues.speaker: VON LUGER
dialogues.text: (coldly - in German) We're ready, Herr Kuhn.

dialogues.speaker: KUHN
dialogues.text: (with studied over- politeness, in English) Perfect, Colorel von Luger. Such efficiency is to be complimented. You may rest assured it will be in my report. Von Luger nods, turns and nods ‘at Strachwitz | who signa "Detonate".

dialogues.speaker: THE PLUNGER , 324
dialogues.text: is depressed...

dialogues.speaker: THE STOVE 325
dialogues.text: shudders...

dialogues.speaker: THE WHOLE APPELL AREA 326
dialogues.text: rumbles...

dialogues.speaker: GROUND 327
dialogues.text: as the subterranean explosions wreck the tunnel and a thi snake of earth forms a depression...

dialogues.speaker: FACES 328
dialogues.text: reacting. Misery. Sickening hopelessness.

dialogues.speaker: KUEN 329
dialogues.text: suddenly laughs. In the dead silence. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: KUHN
dialogues.text: (softly) You'll never escape: Never. You'll never see your homes again. The Herenfolk will conquer the world and make Slaves of your women and children...

dialogues.speaker: IVES 330
dialogues.text: suddenly snaps. Wire happy. He breaks ranks and races madly for the fence, screaming incoherently...

dialogues.speaker: RAMSEY , 331
dialogues.text: appalled.

dialogues.speaker: RAMSEY
dialogues.text: Stop hin!

dialogues.speaker: TWO OFFICERS
dialogues.text: break from the ranks and hare after ives...

dialogues.speaker: FACES 333
dialogues.text: appalled... : FULL SHOT - IVES. | : ‘ 334 frothing, mouthing charges over the warning wire and, hurling himself at the barbed fence, madly tries to tear it to pieces with his bare hands...

dialogues.speaker: TOWER GOON SENTRIES 335
dialogues.text: cover Ives and the two men as they try to pull hin off, but do not fire. Obviously Ives has gone mad.

dialogues.speaker: KUHN 336
dialogues.text: suddenly shrieks, furiously.

dialogues.speaker: KUHN
dialogues.text: (in German) Kill them, you stupid bastards or you'll all be at the Russian front. immediately an SS man jerks his burp gun.

dialogues.text: a sprays bul lets off screen.

dialogues.text: hesitate:, fires a token burst...

dialogues.text: erumple as the bullets cut them down - pock mark the dirt...

dialogues.speaker: RAMSEY
dialogues.text: stares off appalled.

dialogues.speaker: VON LUGER
dialogues.text: appalled - ‘quickly covered.

dialogues.speaker: RANKS OF POW'S
dialogues.text: The SOUND of firing cuts as abruptly as it horrified. started.

dialogues.speaker: RAMSEY
dialogues.text: cold hard,

dialogues.speaker: THE MEN
dialogues.text: shaking with anger.

dialogues.speaker: RAMSEY
dialogues.text: That was murder: Murder! He was mad - wire happy - any one could see that.. they were trying to help him... I demand that...

dialogues.speaker: KUEN
dialogues.text: (cuts him off) You can't demand anything. You're all prisoners of the Reich! Any cne across the wire gets killed. stir in their ranks ominously. Tension. rumble of

dialogues.text: (baiting them) Goon. Please. Gentlemen. Try to escape. The wire is easy to get through. Please - it will save us all 2 lot of trouble! Any one else? Please go on.

dialogues.speaker: HILTS 343
dialogues.text: has his hand up. Others are staring off at Kuhn. Any instant -- any sudden movement ~ villi precipitate the riot. Kuhn walks efposite Hilts. KUHN. (continuing) (walking up) You want to run, hein? (he stops in . front of Hilts) Well, what is it? Hilts ‘suddenly and. savagely belts: Kuhn flat on his bac Not bravado on Hilts' part - just an instinctive battle- bloodlust movement. A fantastic silence.

dialogues.speaker: SS MEN
dialogues.text: jerk their guns into fire position, ready to spray Hilts and, if necessary, the whole rank...

dialogues.text: ashen.

dialogues.text: (violent order) HALT! Nicht sheissen!  352 353 354 355 105.

dialogues.text: hold their positions. Still ready. Kuhn gets up, shaking with rage, the blood pouring from his mouth, he spits out two teeth. Beside himself with fury, grimly looks at von Luger.

dialogues.speaker: STRACHWITZ
dialogues.text: have their guns at the ready. The SS men look around nervously. While all guns cover the POW's there is the faintest suggestion that von Luger's men are also coverin the SS men. Kuhn notices this too - he controls his absolute fury.

dialogues.speaker: KUHN 354
dialogues.text: looks back at Hilts who is almost still in his “battle- coma" - longer time at all the POW's including Ramser - then he turns and stops near von Luger. The same look - @ promise of vengeance to come. Then he stalks away followed by the silent SS men.

dialogues.speaker: RAMSEY 355
dialogues.text: relaxes slightly, but is still grim and dangerously cold.

dialogues.speaker: RAMSEY
dialogues.text: (to von Luger) I demand an immediate interview with the Swiss pepresentative. . von LUGER I will arrange it immediately. (snaps at Strachwitz - in German) Get those soldiers away from the wire. Strachwitz turns, immediately gives the necessary orders, as: VON LUGER (continuing) (to Ramsey) You will no doubt wish a military funeral. I regret the occurrence. (louder, including all the Pow's) Listen to me... There will be no more tunnelling. There will be no more escape attempts. Any one over the warning wire will be shot, On my orders. You are finally warned. He looks off at Hilts who is now out of the "battle-coma” stares back. There is a moment between the two men. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: VON LUGER (continuing) Cooler! Immediately two guards converge on Hilts who calmly begins to walk between them. VON LUGER (continuing) (to Ramsey) Dismiss. He glances off as there is the beginning of en under- current. Yankee Doodle Dandy being softly hummed. By. many men. Very soft. But quite clear.

dialogues.speaker: HILTS 356
dialogues.text: being marched off. ‘ne humming is timed to his march.

dialogues.speaker: FACES OF POW'S 357
dialogues.text: watching, the hum seems to come from nowhere - softly, se softly.

dialogues.speaker: VON LUGER
dialogues.text: . VON LUGER (continuing) Dismiss! : ‘ He walks away, Strachwitz falling’, into step beside him, heads. for main gate as: (quietiy) Dismiss. But unlike before, instead of streaming away, the men stay where they are. Then slowly move into smaller - groups, watching Hilts enter the cooler - the guards : carrying the bodies back. Undercurrent - waves of anger. ‘Bartlett and Ashley-Pitt converge on Ramsey. Cold, angry, brooding violence. The rain patters. RAMSEY (continuing) I want. a report by senior officers! Eyewitness account. in writing. By tomorrow.

dialogues.speaker: ASHLEY-PITT
dialogues.text: Yes, sir. And I'11 make arrangements for burial. (CONTINUED )

dialogues.speaker: RAMSEY
dialogues.text: Who were they?

dialogues.speaker: ASHLEY- PITT
dialogues.text: Baldwin and Meade, DFC.

dialogues.speaker: RAMSEY
dialogues.text: Terrible. Just terrible. Bartlett looks off at Strachwitz and the pathetic bodies. His face closes.

dialogues.speaker: BARTLETT
dialogues.text: Open up Harry. We dig. Around the clock.

dialogues.speaker: ASHLEY-PITT
dialogues.text: But what am I going to do with the dirt? If we so much as spread a teaspoon around, they'll fall on us like iocusts.

dialogues.speaker: BARTLETT
dialogues.text: We'll put it down Dick. They stave at him and the enormity of the idea hits them. Bartlett turns and exits purposefully. They look after hin. : . NEAR MAIN GATE - GUARD DETAIL © . 359 ‘is marching out of the compound. The faces of the guards are grim, cold. The detail passes, heads for the opening gate, Strachwitz near it. Last in line is the Artful Dodger, blatantly marching out with the Germans, heading out of the gate.

dialogues.speaker: STRACHWITZ, 360
dialogues.text: purple with fury. Grabs him:

dialogues.speaker: STRACHWITZ
dialogues.text: (furiously) Zum Teufel, Merivale, three men are killed and you still try this stupidity! (grates) Are you insane? (CONTINUED )

dialogues.speaker: MERIVALE
dialogues.text: (thoughtfully) Yes, I rather suppose I am. (Ledly) Insanity seems to be in the air, hein?

dialogues.speaker: STRACHWITZ
dialogues.text: (angrily) Cooler! Immediately three guards converge, the Dodger walks off whistling. Strachwitz stares after him: , STRACHWITZ (continuing) (almost to himself ) Gott im Himmel, will they never learn!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: oO

dialogues.text: is digging with controlled ferocity. Behind him Willie is shovelling the dirt into a loading "half-bed".

dialogues.text: rake the compound. Many more ferrets. Many more guards amble aimlessly, then suddenly converge for a snap inspection...

dialogues.speaker: BLYTHE . 373
dialogues.text: — wipes his eyes tiredly, then grimly goes back to letter Others work grimly. A sudden signal and all work disap- pears and a ferret enters. Blythe is already lecturing...

dialogues.text: exits from the opening tiredly. Sudden warning: He galvanizes into action. The next man, Danny, hurriedly ducks back into the tunnel as the slab and grating are slammed into place and the water poured into the trap.

dialogues.text: 'Raus, Out! Everyone out!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown

dialogues.text: ducks. down into the ante-room, All the men who were work ing are motionless. Muffled cursing and movements above. A man nervously drops 2 makeshift saw, Seemingly a huge noise. LIveryone holds. his -breath.

dialogues.text: TOILET-Sii0WER - KRAMER - STRACHWITZ 376 make a minute search of the toilet room, knocking cement floors. Then they exit into...

dialogues.text: are ripping the place apart searching for tools, or whatever.

dialogues.speaker: HILTS' CELL
dialogues.text: grimly tosses the baseball against the wall. Again. Again. Then suddenly he stops. Listens intently. He stretches out on the floor, presses his ear against the concrete...

dialogues.speaker: HILTS 379
dialogues.text: as he holds his breath. For an instant the faintest sound impression of tunneling. Hilts listens - straining. Nothing more. Perhaps he imagined it - perhaps not. MERIVALE'S CELL - MERIVALE " 360. + also in solitary in his cell is also listening. Grimly. He gets up, paces around furiously.

dialogues.speaker: HILTS' CELL
dialogues.text: listens, full of impotent rage. Grimly begins doing push-ups.

dialogues.speaker: AHSLEY-PITT 382
dialogues.text: is supervising the dirt being packed against the face of the tunnel. INT. LIBRARY ATTIC ~- NIGHT . KRAMER © 383 pokes his head into the attic, with a flashlight carefull makes sure that there is no dirt there.

dialogues.speaker: FERRETS 384
dialogues.text: look under barracks, making sure there is no extra dirt anywhere. At a window, a stooge guards, his eye pressed to a chink in the slats.

dialogues.speaker: NEAR HENDLEY'S HUT
dialogues.text: 4s walking along, looking under huts, searching as the others are searching. Also with his cordon of counter- ferrets. As Werner turns the corner of Hendley's hut, abruptly he hurries up the steps...

dialogues.speaker: HENDLEY 386
dialogues.text: is lying on his bunk reading. Blythe is there. Hendley pretends surprise as Werner, white and nervous, shuts. th door quickly. He fishes into his uniform and brings out a sm@ll roll of film, almost drops it in his anxiety.

dialogues.speaker: HENDLEY
dialogues.text: (taking it) Werner, you're a living doll!

dialogues.speaker: ON DOOR, (AS IT JERKS OPEN)
dialogues.text: stands there, a deadly calm.

dialogues.speaker: HENDLEY
dialogues.text: Like magic the film disappears into Hendley's sleeve. Werner (back to Strachwitz) is almost paralyzed. Hendley reacts instantly: HENDLEY (continuing) (pretending anger) For Pete's sake, you too Strachwitz? (angrily to Werner) You've been through this hut fifteen times in the last couple of weeks! How many times you gotta be told there's nothing here? ( CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: Werner shrugs, begins to search - covering his petrifying fear. After a pause:

dialogues.speaker: STRACHWITZ
dialogues.text: (to Werner - satisfied) 'Raus. They exit. Hendley exhales and wipes the sweat off and gives Blythe the film.

dialogues.speaker: HENDLEY
dialogues.text: Two seconds earlier and that poor little guy would've been on the Russian front. But Blythe is preoccupied, carefully examining the film. To Henciey's astonishment, Blythe is holding the film an inch or so away from his eyes; Hendley frowns - says nothine.

dialogues.speaker: BLYTHE
dialogues.text: is sitting with: the camera, takes pheto, reveals he is shooting a picture of Hendley dressed in a civilian suit, who heads a line of other POW's dressed in a motley array of costumes. Next in line is Nimmo. Weird windbreaker and pants, beret. He moves into position as Hendley steps aside.

dialogues.speaker: HENDLEY
dialogues.text: (to Nimno) What're you, Nimmo?

dialogues.speaker: NIMMO
dialogues.text: Bulgarian laborer.

dialogues.speaker: HENDIZY
dialogues.text: I didn't know you could speak Bulgarian.

dialogues.speaker: NINO
dialogues.text: I don't, bach. But Celtic sounds enough like it, look you.

dialogues.speaker: BARTLETT
dialogues.text: 4s sitting at his table. Calis out:

dialogues.speaker: BARTLETT
dialogues.text: Next. The docr opens and Cavendish comes in. BARTLETT (continuing) Nun, wir sind sie?

dialogues.text: Je m'appelle Francois Jeville.

dialogues.text: Ach, Franzersich?

dialogues.text: Non, Belgique. .

dialogues.text: Votre permiss?

dialogues.text: (Gives into his uniform with a flourish, comes out empty-handed) Voila! At least forgery 've promised them on time.

dialogues.text: (beat) Sood. Next! Cavendish exits and door opens and Griffiths comes in. BARTIETT (continuing) Nun, wer sind Sie?

dialogues.text: Je suis Gason Seulile di Sec Miolle. francaise.

dialogues.speaker: BARTLETT
dialogues.text: Bien. Et votre place de naissance?

dialogues.text: (faltering) Uh ~ uh.
