dialogues.text: For God's sake, man, you'd know where you were born.

dialogues.speaker: 4HILTS'
dialogues.text: Hilts is bouncing the baseball. Merivale stares stonily out of the barred window high on one wall.

dialogues.speaker: HILTS
dialogues.text: (shouts) Hey, Major! You mind a personal question?

dialogues.speaker: MERIVALE
dialogues.text: Certainly not!

dialogues.speaker: HILTS
dialogues.text: What happened to your hands?

dialogues.speaker: MERIVALE
dialogues.text: Oh == nothing much. At. Gallipoli in the Great War some chaps were in a boat, in the Straits. They were in trouble. I just pulled them out.

dialogues.speaker: HILTS
dialogues.text: How?

dialogues.speaker: MERIVALE
dialogues.text: Had to swim out to them -- had to tow the boat == you know, bullets and all that sort of thing. The rope cut through the tendons of my hands. ,

dialogues.speaker: HILTS
dialogues.text: (reacts - then) What was it? Steel cable?

dialogues.speaker: MERIVALE
dialogues.text: No, it was rather cold and the Tope was frozen.

dialogues.speaker: HILTS
dialogues.text: (after pause) I'm sorry. That's too bad. (CONTINUED )

dialogues.speaker: MERIVALE
dialogues.text: It only takes one finger to pull a trigger. Hilts thinks about this. Suddenly listens intently, presses his ear to the floor.

dialogues.speaker: HILTS
dialogues.text: Hey, Major -= from what I hear Herry's growing inte quite a big boy. Merivale looks up from studying his hands --

dialogues.speaker: MERIVALE
dialogues.text: Yes. It's about time he got out of school.

dialogues.speaker: HILTS
dialogues.text: Sure hope we don't miss graduation.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: is tiredly interrogating POW's. Nimmo exits.

dialogues.speaker: MACDONALD

dialogues.text: Wie heissen Sie?

dialogues.text: Eric Stressel von Munchen.

The shaft ceiling is about twenty-five feet. A firm ladder is tacked to one side. The actual ceiling is only dirt from which roots emanate. Along one side a huge tree root enters the shaft delicately. All talk in whispers, nervous excitement.

dialogues.speaker: BARTLETT
dialogues.text: Yes. Taking hold of his excitement, Danny climbs the ladder, CAMERA FOLLOWING. He carries a small probe and sticks it into the ceiling dirt. He shoves it carefully for eighteen inches, then abruptly there is no more resistance.

dialogues.speaker: . MACDONALD

dialogues.speaker: ASHLEY-PITT
dialogues.text: (closing door) Sleep tight! —

dialogues.speaker: . BARTLETT
dialogues.text: Sit down, Hilts. Have you got all your gear ready? Iron rations?

dialogues.speaker: HILTS
dialogues.text: Yes, thanks. (after pause) Just wanted to ask a couple of questions - if you don't mind.

dialogues.speaker: BARTLETT
dialogues.text: Shoot.

dialogues.speaker: HILTS
dialogues.text: Well. How many-'re going?

dialogues.speaker: BARTLETT
dialogues.text: Two hundred and fifty. Hilts blinks, then smiles feintly.

dialogues.speaker: HILTS
dialogues.text: That's a mighty big number.

dialogues.speaker: BARTLETT
dialogues.text: It's a big plan.

dialogues.speaker: EILTS
dialogues.text: What do you figure our chances? To get that number out? :

dialogues.speaker: BARTLETT
dialogues.text: Excellent. To get them out permanently - very bad. (CONTINUED )

dialogues.speaker: . HILTS
dialogues.text: O (after a pause - perplexed) I thought the whole idea was to -~ well, escape. To get home. Bartlett studies. Hilts thoughtfully.

dialogues.speaker: BARTLETT
dialogues.text: It 1s. At the same time maybe it's not quite so selfish, You might call it awar effort. A lot of fellows are carrying part of the war ball we should be carrying. (beat) I'll make it clear for you. (beat) When one man escapes, this one man diverts about a hundred goons from their war effort if he's caugh? within an hour. A thousand goons if it takes them a day to catch him. Ten thousand if it takes a week. Soldiers - police - mainly. Say we multiply that by two hundred and fifty. Think of the monumental muck up we'd cause the goons. Why we'll o involve millions - if we're lucky! Pos The whole bloody Reich - if we're Co very lucky. - Hilts stares at ham bug-eyed:

dialogues.speaker: HILTS
dialogues.text: I thought I was blitz happy - but you, you're the blitz king of ther all. (beat) Or wire happy! i ‘ BARTLETT To Who am I not to be?

dialogues.speaker: HILTS
dialogues.text: (after a pause) : Say we're not lucky. Say some ys get killed. You think the monumental muck up" would be worth it?

dialogues.speaker: BARTLETT
dialogues.text: If it shortens the war by a day - even by an hour - yes.

dialogues.speaker: _ HILTS
dialogues.text: OC) Say it doesn't. What then? (CONTINUED )

dialogues.speaker: LC
dialogues.text: . That's the measure of my responsibility. Hilts stares at him.

dialogues.speaker: HILTS
dialogues.text: Boy, this is one for the book. (pause) How many you figure'il make it?

dialogues.text: That's up to Lady Luck - or Fate - or God + depending on your point of view. (gently) : Look, Hilts. Escaping is always a very personal decision, always a volunteer operation. No one - Big "X" or the senior officer - no one orders anyone to escape, or not to escape. You wouldn't be wrong if you decided not to go. Hilts stares at him pop eyed:

dialogues.speaker: . HILTS
dialogues.text: . Oh, I'm going. Of course! I just wanted to know the’ odds. Going? Of course I'm going! I just wanted to know the score. Suddenly the air raid siren begins shrieking.

dialogues.speaker: WILLIE
dialogues.text: Danny! Danny! For the love of God... Danny tries to struggle free and Willie, tiny against Danny's bulk, belts him, trying to knock him out but the blow hardly touches Danny. He breaks free. Willie rugger tackles him, crashes him down, drags him under the lee of a hut. Danny stares up petrified at the floor - only a few inches above his head, tunnei-like. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ro

dialogues.text: (desperately) It's caving in again. I'm buried. I can't see! I'm blind -. I'm blind!

dialogues.speaker: WILLIE
dialogues.text: (horrified) It's the lights, Danny. The goons 've cut the bloody lights.

dialogues.speaker: DANNY
dialogues.text: (struggling) Let me out - Let me out! I can't breathe - I'm suffocating...

dialogues.speaker: HELP
dialogues.text: Frightened that the goons will hear, Willie, with super- human strength, pulls him back again and backhands him Savagely. To his horror, Danny starts crying.

dialogues.speaker: WILLIE
dialogues.text: What is it Danny?

dialogues.speaker: DANNY
dialogues.text: (sobbing) The tunnel - it's got me, Willie. I can't stand it any more. Not again. Never. I can't - it's just like I'm puried alive every time -- (desperately) It's tonight or never for me, ' Willie. I can't go down that hole again. I-can't. I just can't. Suddenly Willie stares off. .

dialogues.text: A goon sentry. is searching with a flashlight - his burp gun ready. Then he sees them - the gun covers them!

dialogues.speaker: SENTRY
dialogues.text: (angrily) What you do there! COME OUT!

dialogues.speaker: WILLIE AND DANNY 429
dialogues.text: erawi out. Willie covering Danny. (CONTINUED)
CONTINUED: . hag

dialogues.text: (cesperately) The air raid siren scared him. Sent him a iittle crazy. He's all right now. Come on, Danny. (to the sentry) You know, shell shock. Quickly he hurries Danny away - and Danny, pathetic now, allows himself to be led. Nervously the sentry turns away. CAMERA goes to a window. Hilts is there. His shock shows.

dialogues.speaker: MEN 430
dialogues.text: are getting ready. Changing into their escape suits.

dialogues.speaker: OTHER MEN 431
dialogues.text: are fixing gear.

dialogues.speaker: BLYTHE AND HENDLEY 432
dialogues.text: ‘are dressing. Hendley slips out of the door, heads for the John. Blythe closes the door, his nerves are on edge. He finds a pin, sets it on the edge of the table. orients himself carefully then walks forward’ casually to pick it up. A miss by an inch. He does it again and this time bullseyes on the pin. He gets back into position, waits, sweating with nervousness. Glances at his watch,

dialogues.speaker: MEN 433
dialogues.text: are waiting nervously. Someone drops a book. The slight noise makes everyone jump. CAVENDISH 43h is staring into a mirror, brushing his moustache into violence. :

dialogues.speaker: RAMSEY . 435

dialogues.text: walk up and down, stamping their feet in the damp cold. Overcast sky -- the last gloomy light of day. A burst of. laughter from the guard house and the whining oscil- lation of a radio being tuned in. A German folk song... men's chorus = warms the gloaming.

dialogues.speaker: BLYTHE AND HENDLEY / 438
dialogues.text: wait fidgeting. A lkmock the door opens. Bartlett enters. He still wears his uniform. Grave face.

dialogues.speaker: BLYTHE
dialogues.text: {over friendly) Hello, Cyril. How do we look? (he struts a littie) Guten arbend, mein Herr. Wie geht es ihnen?

dialogues.speaker: . BARTLETT
dialogues.text: (gravely) sorry, Colin. You're eff the list. You can't go!

dialogues.speaker: . BLYTHE
dialogues.text: What're you talking about? Why not?

dialogues.speaker: BARTLETT
dialogues.text: Because you've torn your eyes out. For us.

dialogues.speaker: BLYTHE
dialogues.text: Nonsense. .

dialogues.speaker: BARTLETT
dialogues.text: Look, Colin.

dialogues.speaker: BLYTHE
dialogues.text: (interrupting) I can see as weil as anyone. (looks around) See that pin? (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: BARTLETT
dialogues.text: (looks, then, after pause} Yes. Blythe waiks to it unerringly, picks it up. Coming back, all smiles, he stumbles over a chair which Bartlett quietly put in his way. Blythe stares down appalled, near tears,

dialogues.speaker: HENDLEY
dialogues.text: Is there any need to be so tough?

dialogues.speaker: BARTLETT
dialogues.text: Yes. I'm afraid there is. (to Birthe ) Sorry. I hate this eleventh hour letdown, but I've oniy just been told. It's too risky for you.

dialogues.speaker: HENDLEY
dialogues.text: Don't you think that's Colin's decision, not yours?

dialogues.speaker: BARTLETT
dialogues.text: Not altogether. He'd also be a hazard to the whole escape. . That's my decision,

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: if you want to talk about. . hazards, what about you? You're the biggest hazard of all of us. You're a marked man, Bartlett.

dialogues.speaker: BARTLETT
dialogues.text: (after a pause) Yes. That's true, HENDLEY © Well, none of us have voted you off the list, so you've no right to do the same. Bartlett looks at him. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: . BARTLETT
dialogues.text: If you're asking me how far a commander is allowed to go - or dares to go - or is allowed to play God, I can't answer you. (beat) - But I can tell you a blind man is an unnecessary hazard not only to himself but to the whole plan and therefore will be eliminated.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Iagree. But Colin's going. I'll be his eyes. I'll take care of him. That's my decision. Bartlett looks at him, gauging him. Then the faint smile. .

dialogues.speaker: BARTLETT
dialogues.text: Very well. Good luck. He turns and exits. Hendley stares after him sourly. Blythe takes off his glasses. wipes them.

dialogues.speaker: BLYTHE
dialogues.text: (very matter of : fact) Actually, I suppose after all, it's better if I didn't. Cyril's quite right. Completely right. Fav as blind as the proverbial at.

dialogues.speaker: HENDLEY
dialogues.text: Hell, we'll make it in great shape. And that's the end of it. Blythe replaces his glasses, fiddles with them. A long pause:

dialogues.speaker: BLYTHE
dialogues.text: Would you like some tea? We've got time. Hendley looks up, suddenly vastly amused. He hides it and flattens his voice too:

dialogues.speaker: HENDLEY
dialogues.text: Thanks.

dialogues.speaker: BLYTHE
dialogues.text: Splendid. DISSOLVE To:

dialogues.speaker: BARTLETT 439
dialogues.text: approaches, heading for Ramsey's room. Troubled.

dialogues.speaker: INT, RAMSEY'S ROOM
dialogues.text: RAMSEY 4ho looks up, smiles.

dialogues.speaker: RAMSEY
dialogues.text: ‘Hello, Cyril. I was going to drop by to wish you God speed.

dialogues.speaker: . BARTLETT
dialogues.text: You remember when I just came to the camp, you said perhaps I shoulda stay out of the escape?

dialogues.speaker: RAMSEY
dialogues.text: Yes, I remember.

dialogues.speaker: BARTLETT
dialogues.text: You remember I said I'd tell you if I ever got wire happy?

dialogues.speaker: RAMSEY
dialogues.text: Are you? -

dialogues.speaker: BARTLETT
dialogues.text: I don't know. I don't think so -~ but I'm not sure.

dialogues.speaker: RAMSEY
dialogues.text: Listen Cyril, war's a mucked up way of life. Who knows what's right or what's wrong? Or what's the difference between you and me or that poor man Ives.

dialogues.speaker: BARTLETT
dialogues.text: I feel I'm right to try to get back at the goons <= the only way we can,

dialogues.speaker: RAMSEY
dialogues.text: I agree, Cyril. My concern is the Gestano. (CONTINUED)
4ho

dialogues.speaker: BARTLETY
dialogues.text: You Imow, Cir, you always separate professional soldiers from the Gestapo. To me they're all the same. In fact, I Jmow the Von. Lugers are worse =- they know better. Yet they put the lunatics in power and they're leaving them there.

dialogues.speaker: RAMSEY
dialogues.text: (after pause) I don’t disagree with you, Cyril. I only pointed out a pertinent military fact. (smiles) Shouldn't you be getting ready? (gravely) Perhaps you and I shouldn't ‘try to solve the insolvable. (holds out his hand) Good luck, old chum.

dialogues.speaker: BARTLETT
dialogues.text: Thank you, Sir.

dialogues.speaker: RAMSEY
dialogues.text: God bless. : Bartlett leaves, Closes the'door. Ramsey stares after him gravely.
