dialogues.speaker: SORREN
dialogues.text: Yes. The last of the suitcase carriers have gone through and we're about to start on the - - blanket brigade. That should make things go faster, once we resume. Sit tight, boys. Sorren picks his way back to the washroom. A call comes up from the trap.

dialogues.speaker: MUFFLED VOICE
dialogues.text: Hey - aloft. We're moving again.

dialogues.speaker: CAVENDISH
dialogues.text: Here we go again, Send them along. ) Sorren hurries out of the washroom as Cavendish goes be

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: © 521 522 523 524 525 526 527 528 529 158. INT. “HARRY" AT HALF-WAY HOUSE - NIGHT

dialogues.speaker: GRIFFITHS 521
dialogues.text: arrives, shifts to the next trolley as the first trolley is hauled back, hurtles into tunnel.

dialogues.speaker: AT ENTRANCE SHAFT 522
dialogues.text: Men are coming down the shaft. Cavendish gets on trolley and rolls away.

dialogues.speaker: RAMSEY 523
dialogues.text: paces up and down, glances at his watch repeatedly.

dialogues.speaker: HILTS 524
dialogues.text: watches as he holds the rope's end. He tugs it. A man comes out. Another tug. Griffiths comes out of the hole, starts to run toward the woods. He trips and falls flat on his face, making a thudding noise.

dialogues.speaker: TWO SENTRIES 525
dialogues.text: turn and look off'in the direction of the woods. Another guard appears. The three move closer as they talk. One sentry points up toward the woods. They stand listening.

dialogues.speaker: HILTS 526
dialogues.text: tense, hardly breathing, looking off.

dialogues.speaker: GRIFFITHS 527
dialogues.text: lying prone, not stirring a muscle...

dialogues.speaker: CAVENDISH 528
dialogues.text: holds the signal rope.

dialogues.speaker: CAVENDISH
dialogues.text: Come on cld boy, hurry up!

dialogues.speaker: THE SENTRIES
dialogues.text: as they listen. Then the sentry who heard the noise in the first place starts off toward the woods to investigat holding his burp gun at ready.

dialogues.speaker: GRIFFITHS 530
dialogues.text: lies doggo on the ground as the German sentry comes neare The Germen has been Jooking into the lights for some timc and cannot see clearly in.the increasing darkness as. he proaches the woods. He passes Griffiths, without seeing him, steps on Griffiths' outstretched hand. Griffiths flinches but doesn't move as the German goes past.

dialogues.speaker: HILTS 531
dialogues.text: takes as much cover as he dares without lioving. He watches wide-eyed as the German approaches.

dialogues.speaker: GERMAN SENTRY 532
dialogues.text: moves cautiously to the edge of the woods, looks ail about him tut doesn't see Hilts in the shadows. He turns slowly and starts back towards the fence. New Griffichs is between him and the lights of the comround. He takes a couple of steps toward the compound, then stops, gasps.

dialogues.speaker: HIS FOV
dialogues.text: silhouetted against the lights of the compound in the backgroun?

dialogues.speaker: GERMAN SENTRY 534
dialogues.text: as his eyes widen. He approaches Griffiths cautiously, then seeing clearly who he is, raises, his gun to firing position. :

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: jumps up with a yell -

dialogues.speaker: HILTS
dialogues.text: Don't shoot! Den't shoot!

dialogues.speaker: GERMAN SENTRY 536
dialogues.text: standing over Griffiths, whirls startled, covers Hilts. Behind him, Griffiths jumps up.

dialogues.speaker: GRIFFITHS
dialogues.text: Don't shoot! I give up. Don't shoot! The German sentry whirls back toward Griffiths. Cavendish head pors up out of the whole. The German, appalled, shou inarticuiately. At the same time his gun inadvertently fires into the air. Cavendish disappears, Griffiths raise his hancs. Hilts takes off into the woods. The German whirls, sprays the forest...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sorren, Haynes and the stocge are at the window - all frozen.

dialogues.speaker: HAYNES
dialogues.text: That appears to be a shot.

dialogues.speaker: SORREN
dialogues.text: That was indeed a bloody shot. Someone's caught it. (into the shaft) Hey down there. Fass the word - everyone back from the tunnel. Haynes hares out of the washroom. '

dialogues.speaker: GUARDS 528
dialogues.text: pour out of the guarchouse, hare for the searchlight that has zeroed in on Griffiths who stands paralyzed, his arms above his head. Gutteral shouts. A few isolated shots.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: RAMSEY ; : 53° reacts to the continuing short bursts of firing. very tired. Very concerned. He gets up, grimly erect. Begins to exit. . . .

dialogues.speaker: CAVENDISH 540
dialogues.text: ducks back into the tunnel. Desperate whisper:

dialogues.speaker: CAVENDISH
dialogues.text: Jig's up - the bloody goons... He stares up petrified, as the sentry appears in the hole stares cown at them, menaces them with his burp gun.

dialogues.speaker: GERMAN
dialogues.text: (shouting) 'Raus! 'Raus! SOFORT! He fires. a short warning burst into the earth. Cavendish and the others pour up the ladder. Very fast. Some crouch back into the tunnel, petrified.

dialogues.speaker: HALF-WAY HOUSE 541
dialogues.text: An escapee is backing out of the escape tunnel. Now there's the beginning of a real pile up. And panic.

dialogues.speaker: ESCAPEE
dialogues.text: Bastards. They've knorm all along. They're plugging the blckes as they've been coming out.

dialogues.speaker: ANOTHER ESCAPEE
dialogues.text: Rot! We'd have heard shots before. The goons've just found the hole.

dialogues.speaker: A THIRD ESCAPEE
dialogues.text: Let's get the hell out of here. He dive= for the trolley and starts paddling back.

dialogues.speaker: ENTRANCE SHAFT 542
dialogues.text: An escavee starts back up the shaft to the washroom. One man is at the mouth of the tunnel shouting.

dialogues.speaker: ESCAPEE
dialogues.text: Come. back: Come back! Everyone back! They've found “Harry”! . He starts to pull at the trolley rope.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: An escapee on the trolley moving back to the start of the tunnel. He scrambles off and pushes as close to the ladder as he can.

dialogues.speaker: ESCAPEE
dialogues.text: (to the others) Someone's been shot back there. Hurry. I.think the goons are coming down the tunnel. There was someone just behind me.

dialogues.speaker: MOUTH OF TUNNEL . 544
dialogues.text: Second escapee crawls out of the tunnel and shoves toward the shaft,

dialogues.speaker: SECOND .ESCAPEE
dialogues.text: Hurry up! The goons are coming. I heard one just behind me.

dialogues.speaker: GOFF 545
dialogues.text: is coming out of the washrcom into the corridor. The block seems to be on fire. Sorren comes toward him through the smoke.

dialogues.speaker: GOFF
dialogues.text: Where's the fire?

dialogues.speaker: SORREN
dialogues.text: They're burning the papers.

dialogues.speaker: GOFF
dialogues.text: I heard some of the boys were shot. By goons coming through the tunnei. I'm getting the hell out of here} Goff runs out. One or two escapees run after him.

dialogues.speaker: GOFF AND OTHERS 546
dialogues.text: come tearing out the door, the searchlights pick them ur. Machine guns start to chatter. They run back througn the door. INT. HUT 104 - NIGHT . cLOSs 547 as they come running back into the hut.

dialogues.speaker: SORREN
dialogues.text: Change your mind?

dialogues.speaker: GOFF
dialogues.text: Wouldn't you? Geff laughs but stops as the door bursts open and Strachwicc enters. He is carrying a pistol in his hand. Goes.tc the tunnel mouth, looks down.

dialogues.speaker: VON. LUGER 548
dialogues.text: is nose-to-nose with Griffiths at the front gate. Von Luger's collar is unbuttoned and he has a pistol in his hands. At his side is Posen with a great coat over his pajamas.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: Behind them, armed guards: in formation doudle-time from the guardhouse through the inner gate into the compound. A group heads into the forest - sporadic gun fire, gutter commands. Von Luger is literally foaming.

dialogues.speaker: VON LUGER
dialogues.text: So, you don't want to stay in this camp, eh! COOLER: (shouts at a guard - in German) Get ‘em all into appell? I ONCE. Von Luge~ turns away and hurries toward the compound. Posen shzkes his head angrily, a stream of German...

dialogues.speaker: AT HUT 104 549
dialogues.text: POU'S stream out to find the hut completely ringed by helmeted armed guards.

dialogues.speaker: STRACHWITZ'S VOICE
dialogues.text: Out. Out. Everyone out. Ausgahan. Schnell. Each prisoner is made to strip to his underwear as he comes out of the hut. Strachwitz and the goons are rough with those who resist. . . .

dialogues.speaker: GOFF , . .
dialogues.text: struggles to keep his pants. Von Luger enters ani points to Goff. Govier! VON LUGER ooler? Two armed guards march Goff off as the goons start chivvy the other prisoners into three ranks as Von Luger watches

dialogues.speaker: A. PRISONER
dialogues.text: It's too cold to stand here like this + what sort of nonsense are you up to? Von Luger points to him.

dialogues.speaker: VON LUGER
dialogues.text: Cooler, Two guards march this prisoner after Goff. As they do - (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: ANOTHER PRISONER
dialogues.text: Coo, we are in a pet, aren't we? Von Luger points to him.

dialogues.speaker: VON LUGER
dialogues.text: Cooler. Two guards march this one away, too. Von Luger draws his »xistol.

dialogues.speaker: VON LUGER
dialogues.text: If there are any more disturbances I will personally shoot two of you. The ranics of prisoners quiet down, their eyes on Von Lug The whole camp is being shoved into appell...

dialogues.speaker: RAMSEY 551
dialogues.text: joins the lineup. He sees Sorren.

dialogues.speaker: RAMSEY
dialogues.text: (whispers ) How many got ‘out?

dialogues.speaker: SORREN
dialogues.text: (whaspers’) - Don't know exactly, sir. Maybe forty.

dialogues.speaker: VON LUGER . 552
dialogues.text: shaking with rage, dangerous, walks along the ranks of men...

dialogues.speaker: VON LUGER
dialogues.text: You're going to stand there till we find out who's missing. If it takes ten hours! Do you understand? If it takes ten days! Is that clear? If it takes ten years! Do I make myself plain? He comes face to face with Ramsey. A moment, then with @ great effort, Von Luger controls himself.

dialogues.speaker: STRACHWITZ 553
dialogues.text: with the other ferrets has not quite completed herding all of the prisoners into line. They are still stalling for time, milling about, pretending confusion. Strachwitz grabs a burp gun from a guard, lays a long burst of pullets just over the heads of a group of the men. Silenc Immediate order as Strachwitz jars in a new clip.

dialogues.speaker: NONCOM
dialogues.text: Answer to your names, Adams? Adams?... Arlen. Arlen.

dialogues.speaker: A VOICE
dialogues.text: Here.

dialogues.speaker: NONCOME
dialogues.text: Baleen? Baleen?... Bartlett. Bartlett?...

dialogues.speaker: SERIES OF SHOTS 554
dialogues.text: as lights go on in building, phones are seen being answerec. Headlights of cars and motorcycles glare as they turn out of entry ways, roar off down deserted streets.

dialogues.speaker: THE WHOLE CAMP "555
dialogues.text: is still at appell. Surrounded by helmeted Wehrmacht Guards. Ramsey in front. Von Luger in front of him. The last of the POW's goes through a team of men who have been making a photo-check, wearily joins. the main body of POW's. The senior non-com tallies a slip of paper, gives it to Strachwitz, an SS man takes the slip arrogantly, looks at it, hands it back - stalks towards main gate. Impassive, Strachwitz glances at the slip, takes it to Posen. Posen glances at it, gives it to Von Luger.

dialogues.speaker: VON LUGER 556
dialogues.text: is erect, motionless. But his face is grey and his eyes ved-rimmed. He reads the slip. His face sags.

dialogues.speaker: VON LUGER
dialogues.text: (barely audible) Sechs und siebensig?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: including Sorren. Whicpers:

dialogues.speaker: VOICES
dialogues.text: How many? How many got away? Over fifty? I couldn't hear. I was the last. I saw the figures! Well come on for God's sake! Seventy six! The number is taken up, whispered with the whine of the wind. Exultance = waves of excitement - but held down.

dialogues.speaker: RAMSEY 558
dialogues.text: listens. He hears the number. His face doesn't change. He stares at Von Luger who is looking at him cully.

dialogues.speaker: VON LUGER
dialogues.text: (clears throat) Dismiss!

dialogues.speaker: RAMSEY
dialogues.text: (turns - a command) Dismiss!

dialogues.speaker: THE PARADE
dialogues.text: salutes, Ramsey returns it, then the POW's break and collect into little groups. Growing roars of success...

dialogues.speaker: VON LUGER
dialogues.text: and Germans march grimly out of the compound.

dialogues.speaker: TELEPHONE 561
dialogues.text: grinds into life. The room is German middle-class. decor. The only light is the cold gray dawn seeping through a curtained window. A man-comes through a doorway leading to a becroom, tying his robe belt. His face is puffy with sleep and his hair is missed. As he passes 2 shaft of light - KUEN!

dialogues.speaker: KUEN
dialogues.text: (picks up receiver) Ja?... Stalag Luft?... Und?... Und? Wieviel? (his voice tightens) Sechs und siebensig?... Unglaublich... Ja... Ja... Gewiss. He slams down the receiver, hurries back to the bedroom.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lines of helmeted soldiers in full field packs, comb the undergrowth. A distant burst of machine gun fire. CAMERA MOVES to reveal Danny and Willie hiding. They sneak deeper and deeper into the foliage. In the middle distanc a guard starts running - a dim figure fleeing ahead. Burst of machine gun:

dialogues.speaker: VOICE
dialogues.text: (faintly) Don't shoot - Nich Shiessen! I give up... Oh Christ, Johnny's caught it! The guards grab the dim figure, hurry him into the open. In a moment other guards carry out a badly wounded POW.

dialogues.speaker: DANNY. AND WILLIE 563
dialogues.text: hare away. All around there are grim searchers. Dogs bay on the wind.

dialogues.speaker: GUARDS 564
dialogues.text: halt traffic on a main road. Military convoys: - civilian trucks. Beginning of a pile up. The main artery slows to a.crawl - each vehicle is searches.

dialogues.speaker: HENDLEY, BLYTHE 565
dialogues.text: come down a@ small side road that approaches the station. There is a sprinkling of people on the station platform, pacing about as they wait for the train to arrive. Hendley goides Blythe towards the station waiting room, nto it. *

dialogues.speaker: HENDLEY 566
dialogues.text: looks about the room aghast. Two-thirds of the people are escapees., all sitting nervously, studiously ignoring each other. Among them are Bartlett, MacDonald, Merivale, and Ashley-Pitt who glances absentiy at the new arrivals as do others in the room.including the real Germans. Hendley leads Blythe out again.

dialogues.speaker: HENDLEY 567
dialogues.text: pulls Blythe back against the wall of the builcing.

dialogues.speaker: BLYTHE
dialogues.text: Trouble?

dialogues.speaker: HENDLEY
dialogues.text: (whispers) The place is loaded with our guys. I guess everybody's missed their connections and get jammed up here. I think we- He looks eff. A police car is coming down the road. It is moving vast and blasts its siren-horn to clear the way around a truck. Hurriedly Hendley takes Blythe and they duck into a doorway.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: react to the dying siren. The police car is heard stoppin outside. A moment, then the door bursts open and two police officers come in, look about the room. The escapees almost jump out of their skins as they attempt bland interest. The first policeman spots what he is looking for - a telphone - and heads for it. Getting his ‘ number he rattles off a long string of German. This cau @ murmur of excitement among the real Germans in the room A woman sitting next to Merivale turns and speaks to him in German. He nods enthusiastically - not understanding a word she says. As the woman turns back to listen to the policeman on the phone once more, Merivale turns to Ashle Pitt who is sitting next to him, stares at him questionin ly. During this, the policeman waiting at the door, becom ing aware cf Merivale and Ashley-Pitt, regards them . suspiciously. The first policeman hangs up the phone an heads for the door, ealls briskly for his associate to follow. Escapees breathe inaudible sighs of relief.

dialogues.speaker: HENDLEY, BLYTHE . 569
dialogues.text: The whistle of an approaching train.

dialogues.speaker: . BLYTHE
dialogues.text: Where do we buy tickets?

dialogues.speaker: HENDLEY
dialogues.text: On the train. Taking Blythe's arm, he guides him into position.

dialogues.speaker: BARTLETT AND MACDONALD 570
dialogues.text: make their way along the platform as the train pulls in. The piatform crowds - civilians of all types, foreign workers, military personnel. The other escapees spread themselves as the train stops. Passengers descend. Others board. Bartlett and MacDonald move through the crowd looking for a compartment.

dialogues.speaker: HENDLEY AND BLYTHE BT2
dialogues.text: get aboard a coach near the end of the train as do some others of the escapees.

dialogues.speaker: BARTLETT AND MACDONALD 572
dialogues.text: approach a forward car which has compartments that open to the outside. Bartlett, opens the door of ohe which seems empty, for MacDonald, who gets in quickly, freezes.

dialogues.speaker: FOUR SS OFFICERS . 573
dialogues.text: are side by side on the long seat. Two are dozing. One is reading a manual. The other “is cleaning his néils. The one cleaning his nails glances idly at MacDonald. STATION MASTER'S VOICE. Einsteigen. Somewhere 2 whistle blows.

dialogues.speaker: MACDONALD 574
dialogues.text: stands in the aisle, paralyzed. Bartlett looks down at the feet of one of the dozing SS officers, glares at him and clears his throat loudly.

dialogues.speaker: THE SS OFFICER 575
dialogues.text: who is cleaning his nails, nudges the sleeper who awakens sits up, puts his feet down.

dialogues.speaker: SS OFFICER
dialogues.text: Entschuldigen Sie.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ‘O

dialogues.speaker: BARTLETT AND MACDONALD . 576
dialogues.text: stow their luggage and overcoats and sit down, the SS officer reading the manual lights a cigar, looks Bartlett gad MacDonald over with casual interest. Bartlett takes a folded Paris newspaper, LeSoir, out of his pocket, whips it open, gives MacDonald half, starts to read. The train starts to move.

dialogues.speaker: HENDLEY AND BLYTHE 577
dialogues.text: sit near the rear of the car. As the train gains speed Hendley looks back through the window...

dialogues.speaker: MOVING 578
dialogues.text: Two pelice cars pull up at the station. Pelice pile out of the cavs, hurry into the station building.

dialogues.speaker: HENDLEY 579
dialogues.text: Exhales, leans back in his seat, studies the other occupants of the sparsely filled car. The seats immediate around Hendley and Biythe are empty.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: THE TRAIN . se 580 passes by - rattles across the bridge. that passes over @ small river. ‘On the road paralleling the tracks, Danny and Willie. trudge along. The sound of approaching motors emerges from. the diminishing sound of the train. Danny and Willie run off the road.

dialogues.speaker: UNDER THE BRIDGE 581
dialogues.text: Danny and Willie come down the embankment, hide under the arch of the bridge as a dozen military motorcycles zoom by overhead. The last of these have sidecars carrying praca men. Danny glances off, reacts, runs off. Willie ollows,

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The road is narrow and winds through a thick forest. Hilt comes up out of a deep ravine. Standing at the edge of th road, he studies its relation to the ravine. Makes some mental calculations, then takes the piano wire from his pocket (now tied together in one long ‘single length) anc crossing the road, ties one end of it to a tree. ( CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: He lays the wire sleck across the road on a bias to the edge of the ravine. Picking up a heavy branch, he ties the end of the wire to the top end of the branch. The sound of approaching motors. Hilts grabs the branch, runs back to the cover of the trees beyond the ravine. Places thc branch as a lever ard braces himself.

dialogues.speaker: THE COVEY OF MOTORCYCLES 583
dialogues.text: that pavsed Danny and Willie, comes roaring around the corner in single file, stretched out now by the winding road. One by one the motorcycles zoom across the slack wire on the road. Between the last and the next to last, Hilts hauls the wire taut. The motorcycle (with sidecar) caroms along the slanting wire and is deflected into the ravine. It disappears from sight, a thump is heard, then silence, except for the sound of the departing motorcycle

dialogues.speaker: RAVINE
dialogues.text: are sprawled in the ravine - out cold. Ignoring them, Hilts goes directly to the motorcycle, goes over it to see if it is seriously damaged. Almost tenderly, as if it were a friend who had taken a fall. Finally satisfied, he turns his attention to the inert Germans. Tries one of the helmets on. Too big. Tries the other. It's okay. EXT. RIVERS EDGE = DAY . A TINY ROWBOAT ‘ 585 bebs in the water. Danny and Willie rush down, Danny Picks up the oars. Willie unties and shoves off.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: as Hilts wheels his motorcycle out of the ravine, climbs aboard. The outfit he has put together from the two Germa doesn't look too ill-fitting.

dialogues.speaker: HILTS 587
dialogues.text: starts the machine. Roars off.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: as Hilts barrels flat out into the turn, loses it, and flies across a ditch and plasters the motorcycle and himself onto a field.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: as Hilts hops around the fields in pain, hanging on te hi leg. He stops, looks at the motorcycle reproachfully.

dialogues.speaker: THE TRAIN 590
dialogues.text: comes to a stop. On the platform amongst the travelers are three policemen accompanied by two armed members of the Wehrmacht. The search begins. First the outside compartments.

dialogues.speaker: BARTLETT AND MACDONALD . 591
dialogues.text: react. The door opens and a Policeman enters. He barely glances at the identity cards offered by the SS officers. He studies Bartlett and MacDonald's papers carefully.

dialogues.speaker: POLICE OFFICIAL
dialogues.text: Frankreich?

dialogues.speaker: BARTLETT
dialogues.text: Oui.

dialogues.speaker: MACDONALD
dialogues.text: Moi aussi. The official hands back their papers.

dialogues.speaker: OFFICIAL
dialogues.text: (moving on) Sehr gut;

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hendley, Blythe, Merivale, Ashley-Pitt and the others wai - nervous - uncertain what is happening.

dialogues.speaker: THE CONDUCTOR . 593
dialogues.text: signals the engineer to proceed and then climbs aboard th train as it pulls out.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: AS the train picks up speed, Hendley leaves his seat, murmurs to Blythe:

dialogues.speaker: HENDLEY
dialogues.text: Think I'd better see what's going on. (CONTINUED )

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: He moves through the doors into the coach ahead. .

dialogues.speaker: BLYTHE, ASHLEY-PITT
dialogues.text: wait tensely. In a moment Hendley reenters the coach, tap Blythe and leads the way back in the coach. As he passes Ashley-Pitt he whispers:

dialogues.speaker: HENDLEY
dialogues.text: Tallyho! Ashley-Pitt grimly decides to brazen it out, sits back firmly. As he does so, Merivale gets up, goes into the W.C. and closes the door,

dialogues.speaker: HENDLEY AND BLYTHE 596
dialogues.text: come out.

dialogues.speaker: HENDLEY
dialogues.text: Colin, we'd never make the interrogation going on up there. He moves Blythe to the lower step on the side of the car. Blythe squints at the rugged and precipitous countryside going by fast.

dialogues.speaker: BLYTHE
dialogues.text: Are we “going to jump?

dialogues.speaker: HENDLEY
dialogues.text: I'll tap you when.

dialogues.speaker: BLYTHE
dialogues.text: I'd prefer it if you'd simply give me a sound push, old chap. A reasonably smooth section of the embankment comes into view. Hendley gives Blythe a heave. Jumps off after him.

dialogues.speaker: HENDLEY AND BLYTHE
dialogues.text: 4 hit the embankment. Half running, half falling, they fly down the sloping embankment of the tracks to a crash stop at the foot of some trees. As the train goes out of sight Hendley picks himself up, goes to Blythe.

dialogues.speaker: HENDLEY
dialogues.text: All right? (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: Blythe nods "yes" but inéicates with a gesture his breath is knocked ovt. His glasses are still on his nose - the glass shattered. His fingers tell him his ciothes are badly tern. Hendley goes over his own ripped and stained clothes. HENDLEY (continuing) (disgusted) First we can't handle the language. Now the papers you sweated over won't do us any good. I've really loused this up.

dialogues.speaker: BLYTHE
dialogues.text: (getting his breath) Now what?

dialogues.speaker: HENDLEY
dialogues.text: (sits down) I den't know. Let me think.

dialogues.speaker: COACH 598
dialogues.text: The train is slowing down now as it swings into the turns cf a steep grade. The police are completing their ex- amination of ‘the passengers. One of them goes’ to the he of the car followed by the two soldiers as the other finishes his scrutiny of Ashley-Pitt's papers.

dialogues.speaker: POLICEMAN
dialogues.text: (handing them back) Sehr gut.

dialogues.speaker: ASHLEY -PITT
dialogues.text: Danke. - The first policeman notices the W.C., knocks, then tries the door. It ts locked.

dialogues.speaker: POLICEMAN
dialogues.text: (curtly) Ausmachen! Polizer! Sofort!

dialogues.speaker: IN THE W.C.
dialogues.text: reacts. He looks about the tiny compartment anxiously, sees a small hatch-type air vent in the roof above it.

dialogues.speaker: IN THE CAR CORRIDOR
dialogues.text: raps angrily on the door, tells the conductor to unlock the door. The door crashes open. The W.C. is empty. The policeman looks about the little room astonished. The conductor snaps the handle of the door back and forth, ventures the opinion it wasn't locked - only stuck. The policemun accepts this, moves on.

dialogues.speaker: MERIVALE 601
dialogues.text: lies flat on top of the train. He stares ahead - gasps. The front part of the train is entering a tunnel - a smal storne-faced oval which makes a tight fit for the train. He:-watches the tunnel approach and as the car he is on goes into it, the screen becomes obscured and then black with the boiling smoke from the engine. After a few seconds, the train emerges from the tunnel into the sun light again and the smcke dissipates. Merivale is gone!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: as. the smoke left by the train swirls clear we see Meriv hanging by his hands from the wooden cross members that hold signal wires at the top of the tunnel. He drops to the tracks, observes his bruised. hands then takes off up the cinders. “EXT. ROAD - HILL COUNTRY - DAY

dialogues.speaker: HILTS 603
dialogues.text: is moving along sedately on his motorcycle. Seeing some- thing ahead, he eases back on the throttle.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Many vehicles are lined up in both directions as police Search ‘them, examine the papers of the irritated occupan

dialogues.speaker: HILTS . 605
dialogues.text: looks about for some way to avoid this. There is none. Assuming a nonchalant air, he proceeds.

dialogues.speaker: AT THE BARRIER
dialogues.text: Slows his motorcycle toa bare crawl and politely and casually weaves it between the closely parked double row of vehicles. As he squeezes his way by the examining Gestapo men and police. (CONTINUED )

dialogues.speaker: HILTS
dialogues.text: Heil Hitler! The man reacts mechanically. Hilts continues slowly until clear of the vehicles, then picks up speed.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: smiles, pleased with himself.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A wide sweep of the broad river past a towering castle. In the middle, the tiny rowboat is going down stream. And not far behind it, the tributary it left.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: is rowing, Willie fishes happily from the stern.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: and two other escapees race through the woods in a desper mun. Behind them, the baying of dogs...

dialogues.speaker: THE ESCAPEES . . 611
dialogues.text: fight their way through “the undergrowth, Slip, half fall get up, race on...

dialogues.speaker: HUNDFUHRERS AND DOGS
dialogues.text: charge in pursuit. Twenty or thirty soldiers lope along, burp guns ready. One sees something ahead, Stops, fires a burst.

dialogues.speaker: SEDGWICK AND ESCAPEES 613
dialogues.text: find themselves boxed in. No escape now. Desperately they begin to fan out, toss their documents away, compass etc. One shins up a tree, another darts for a bush, gets under, Sedgwick desperately tries to scale the rockface o the ravine...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: burst out into the open. A soldier reacts, fires a burst of bullets...

dialogues.speaker: SEDGWICK 615
dialogues.text: freezes as the bullets spray around him. Miraculously he is unhurt. .

dialogues.speaker: FULL SHOT 616
dialogues.text: as all the escapees are herded together. Roughly.

dialogues.speaker: GERMAN PASROL BOAT 617
dialogues.text: has a tug with a string of barges stopped. Police search. The beginning of a foul-up in the river - the barges get tangled. Curses. In the distance, another patrol boat scurries after a freighter. In the far distance the tiny rowboat heads down stream.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: cars . 618 full of SS men take off to join the search.

dialogues.speaker: TROOPS 619
dialogues.text: hurry out - in column - or in trucks to join the search. EXT, HUGE STATION - Day -

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There is a monumental foul-up as police and SS men block trains, check passes. Lines of patient - and impatient - civilians. .

dialogues.speaker: INTERSECTION 621
dialogues.text: Roads go in several directions. Maze of signs including temporary military markers using code deSignations as wel as norm.l place and distance route signs. A police car, half hicden, is parked nearby.

dialogues.speaker: HILTS 622
dialogues.text: pulls to a stop, studies the signs - all of which are unintelligible to him. Decides on a route, takes off.

dialogues.speaker: THE POLICE 623
dialogues.text: watch as Hilts leaves.

dialogues.speaker: SECOND INTERSECTION
dialogues.text: is again confronted with a forest of signs. Makes another blind choice, turns to the left.

dialogues.speaker: THE POLICE CAR 625
dialogues.text: One of the policemen gets the other's attention, points.

dialogues.speaker: HILTS 626
dialogues.text: has made a circle, comes back to the same intersection he has just left, stops, confused. Behind him the police car pulls out, starts toward him. Seeing them, Hilts takes off again. The police car SOUNDS its siren. Hiits opens the threttle. .

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: as Hilts loses the police car, broadsiding the motorcycle and sidecar around sharp turns and into narrow side stree Finally gets a road out of town, loses the chasing police car. Temporarily. EXT. ROAD - Day MERIVALE a . 628 marches along at a good clip. He steps ‘aside as a good quality car passes, stops. A moment's indecision, then Merivale brightens as he realizes the driver 4s offering him a ride. .

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Strings of barges and other river traffic work up river. The little rowboat goes by them on its way down river. Danny's head is bent as he bends to the oars in a steady long stroke.

dialogues.speaker: WILLIE
dialogues.text: Spell you for a turn. Danny shakes his head. Then stops rowing momentarily, looking baci.

dialogues.speaker: DANNY
dialogues.text: (a warning) Willie! (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: Willie looks bac, takes out a pipe, lights it, and holds the fishing line:

dialogues.speaker: POLICE LAUNCH 630
dialogues.text: overhauls the rowboat.

dialogues.speaker: ON THE ROWBOAT
dialogues.text: holds up a string of fish, waves | the patrol boat away w an irritated gesture which says “don't scare away the "fish". The launch veers off and speeds away.

dialogues.speaker: WILLIE
dialogues.text: Amazing the courtesy one fisherman shows another. (reacts to string of fish) Danny, can't I chuck 'em overboard - they're getting dreadfully ripe.

dialogues.speaker: DANNY
dialogues.text: When you catch some more! Vaillie puts the fish back down in the bottom of the boat Turns his head to the wind. . EXT. ROAD _- OPEW COUNTRY - DAY - .

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The road rises sharply and drops off sharply as it turns. Hilts comes tearing over the rise in the motorcycle and sidecar, climbs the hill, goes down the other side where he turns off the road suddenly and disappears into the trees, where he is completely hidden. The German police car hurtles in pursuit, bounces up and down the hill and almost turns over on the turn at the bottom of the hill.

dialogues.speaker: RILTS
dialogues.text: watches the departing car. Thinks for a moment. Nods his head. Then begins to unhook the sidecar.

dialogues.speaker: BARTLETT , 634
dialogues.text: and MacDonald stretch tirediy. Bartlett nods to MacDonald who goes to sleep. Now the compartment is crowded. Blinds down for blackout. A few sleepy passengers watch him curiously.

dialogues.speaker: ASHLEY -PITT 635
dialogues.text: sits on his: suitcase in the jammed corridors, grimly tries to sleep. Beyond him, cther escapees try to make themselves inconspicuous. The train begins to slow. Another station.

dialogues.speaker: GUARDS, POLICE, SS MEN 636
dialogues.text: are already herding. passengers-to-be into lines for identity check. Hundreds of security guards - hundreds of muttering, cursing civilians and troops going or coming on leave.

dialogues.speaker: ANNOUNCEMENT
dialogues.text: (in German) All leaves cancelled. All Soldiers are to report back to their barracks. Immediately. Disgruntled Soldiers begin. to shove back. More foul up.

dialogues.speaker: 8S. OFFICER 637
dialogues.text: one of Kuhn's ghouls, sits at a desk. Behind him, a bare room - odd lighting - sinister - chilling. Beside him a gestapo man in civilian dress. Sedgewick stands before em.

dialogues.speaker: SS OFFICER
dialogues.text: Where were you going, Sedgwick?

dialogues.speaker: SEDGWICK
dialogues.text: I hadn't quite decided. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: SS OFFICER
dialogues.text: What information were you to collect on the way? (Sedgwick laughs) What sabotage directions did you receive? (Sedgwick laughs

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: again) Wheat have you done with your papers?

dialogues.speaker: SEDGWICK
dialogues.text: Papers?

dialogues.speaker: SS OFFICER
dialogues.text: Forged papers and identity cards. Don't be stupid. What did you do with them?

dialogues.speaker: SEDGWICK
dialogues.text: (hard) All I've done is escape from a prison camp. You'd do the same if you'd been locked up for. three years. f SS OFFICER iat" You're wearing civilian clothes. oO You're a spy. Spies are shot.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This is my uniform. I had to recut it when I lost weight. Then I dyed it with boot~polish to cover some oil smears I Picked up when I was shot down.

dialogues.speaker: SS OFFICER
dialogues.text: And you lost your insignia over the years?

dialogues.speaker: SEDGWICK
dialogues.text: Too right! The SS officer nods to the police official who presses a button on his desk. A police guard enters and waits.

dialogues.speaker: SS OFFICER
dialogues.text: (in German) Fut him with the others. Send in the next. Sedgwick is taken out. O ‘ s:DISSOLVE To:  i.) 638 €39
INT. COnRIDOR ~ NIGHT

dialogues.speaker: A CELL DOOR
dialogues.text: has a large S scrawled in chalk on it. The GUARD comes down the corridor with Sedgwick and a WARDER carrying a ring of keys. The warder opens the door and the guard pushes Sedgwick into the cell.

dialogues.speaker: SEDGWICK , 639
dialogues.text: enters and the door is slammed shut behind him. The cell is filled with escapees -. more than a score.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hello. Can't say I'm HEEPY to see you again,

dialogues.speaker: . ESCAPES 2
dialogues.text: Just picked up?

dialogues.speaker: SEDGWICK
dialogues.text: This morning.

dialogues.speaker: ESCAPEE 1
dialogues.text: You've set the record so far, if that's any comfort. Most of us were picked up the first day.

dialogues.speaker: SEDGWICK
dialogues.text: What're they going to do-with . us?

dialogues.speaker: ESCAPEE 2
dialogues.text: Didn't you see the S on the door? They're sending us back to Sagan.

dialogues.speaker: SEDGWICK
dialogues.text: That's not so bad.

dialogues.speaker: ESCAPEE 1
dialogues.text: Unless the S stands for Schiesen.

dialogues.speaker: ESCAPEE 3
dialogues.text: They're not going to shoot anyone! They always say that! (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: SEDGWICK
dialogues.text: Why don't we ask the goons and settle it?

dialogues.speaker: ESCAPEE 3
dialogues.text: We did. He said it stands for “shut up".

dialogues.speaker: HILTS 640
dialogues.text: is holed up in the brush near.a road. He is grimly trying to masticate some "iron rations". He swallows ea piece gamely. Wished he hadn't. Reacts as a column of troop trucks begins to go past, sinks deeper into cover.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: FULL SHOT 6ht The platforms are crowded with troops - civilians - cordo off as-everycne is I.D. checked by the police. The train pulls into the station, stops. ‘BARTLETT AND MACDONALD ' , 642 leave the train, start for the exit .@ate to the station waiting room. -A line has formed at the. gate where polic - are checking papers. Bartlett and MacDonald get in line

dialogues.speaker: ASHLEY-PITT . 643
dialogues.text: is. still on the train. A detachment of police moves through the car. They check his identity card, move on. Ashley-Pitt looks out the window of the car, reacts violently to:

dialogues.speaker: KUHN 644
dialogues.text: is stancing on the platform, accompanied by police and two SS men. His back is to the line where Bartlett and MacDon2ié ere, as his eyes search the platform.

dialogues.speaker: ASHLEY -
dialogues.text: goes to the door of the car. Looks off at Bartlett and MacDonald, then at Kuhn, uncertain what to do.

dialogues.speaker: KUHN 646
dialogues.text: turns teward Ashley-Pitt who shrinks back into the car vestibule as he and the SS men walk down the side of th: car, stop directly cpposite the door.

dialogues.speaker: BARTLETT 647
dialogues.text: in the line, glances back briefly at the train. At that tnstant Kuhn looks in his direction, stops as if shot. Bartlett glences away, not having seen Kuhn. Kuhn pulls out his revolver, hurries towards Bartlett...

dialogues.speaker: ASHLEY -PITT 648
dialogues.text: jumps down from the train, hurls himself at Kuhn in a flying rugzer tackle, pole-axes him down, grabs at the gu Violent struggle. Kuhn fires at Ashley-Pitt, misses as AsHKley-Pitt jerks the gun into Kuhn's chest. The gun goes off as SS men try te drag Ashley-Pitt off. In the melee, Ashley-Pitt breaks away --flees down the platform.

dialogues.speaker: BARTLETT AND MACDONALD 649
dialogues.text: lock bee!: startled. Appalled, they notice the SS men grouped around Kuhn's body, and one SS man running throug the crowd after someone. They react, duck out of line, into the vestibule, across the far platform...

dialogues.speaker: ANOTHER .ANGLE
dialogues.text: get through the train and down the other side onto the tracks, run.away...

dialogues.speaker: ASHLEY-PITT /
dialogues.text: “hares down the platform in escape as SS man shouts to the crowds to get out of the way. Exasperated, one of the SS men fires in the air. The crowds scatter. Then he aims at Ashley-Pitt, fires a short burst..

dialogues.speaker: ASHLEY -PITT
dialogues.text: “Slams against the train as the bullets cut him across th back. He staggers on a step or two, collapses, blood streaming frer his mouth. SS men and crowd surround him. Gutteral voices:

dialogues.speaker: VOICES
dialogues.text: (in German) What the hell's going on? One of those damned escapees... Impossible... Certainly looks like it... Get away from here... (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: An SS man turns Ashley-Pitt over roughly.

dialogues.speaker: SS MAN
dialogues.text: Your name? YOUR NAME?

dialogues.speaker: ASHLEY-PITT
dialogues.text: (imperceptibly - - dyin z) Lt. Commander Ashiey-Pitt. DSO. RN. EXT. RAILROAD YARD - TRACKS - HIGHWAY BRIDGE - Day BARTLETT - MACDONALD ‘ 653 running full speed. They weave between the cars and engines sitting on the siding tracks of the yard, make taeir way across a steel bridge spanning a highway and down the stairs to the street level. Pausing there, they look back, see the police have lost them in the yard, the hurry down the street. .

dialogues.speaker: AROUND THE CORNER
dialogues.text: partly filled with people, is ready to.pull out from its starting platform adjoining the station building. Casually, Bartlett and MacDonald get on the front car, Sit on the far side at an open window. The MOTORMAN: clangs the be21 in preparation to start.

dialogues.speaker: VOICE
dialogues.text: Halt doch aie locomotive, bitte. Bartlett and MacDonald look off. A Gestapo motor car is parked on the far side of the train. Two men get out of the motorcar, come over to the train. Politely, pleasant

dialogues.speaker: GESTAPO MAN
dialogues.text: (pleasantly - to Bartlett/NacDonald) Ausweise, bitte. Bartlett and MacDonald hand him their papers. GESTAPO MAN (continuing) (examin. papers - smiles Ah Franzoesisch?

dialogues.speaker: BARTLETT
dialogues.text: Jawcehl. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: GESTAPO MAN
dialogues.text: Com merchantes?

dialogues.speaker: BARTLETT
dialogues.text: Mais oui. Vous parlez Francais?

dialogues.speaker: GESTAPO MAN
dialogues.text: Un peu.

dialogues.speaker: BARTLETT
dialogues.text: Votre accent est tres bon.

dialogues.speaker: GESTAPO MAN
dialogues.text: Je l'ai estudie dans l'ecole superieure, (returns papers) Eh bien. Passez. He gestures to the motorman to go ahead.

dialogues.speaker: BARTLETT
dialogues.text: Merci.

dialogues.speaker: CDONALD
dialogues.text: Merei. ms The train begins tc move slowly.

dialogues.speaker: GESTAPO MAN
dialogues.text: (to Bartlett) Au revoir, monsieur.

dialogues.speaker: BARTLETT
dialogues.text: Au revoir. The Gestapo man smiles at MacDonald, softly:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: “Good luck, chum!

dialogues.speaker: MACDONALD
dialogues.text: > Thanks. Instantly, MacDonald reacts with sickened horror at his slip. Guns now cover them.

dialogues.speaker: GESTAPO MAN
dialogues.text: Halt! (snarls at Bartlett and MacDonald) Out! Immediately!

dialogues.speaker: LIST OF ESCAPEES 655
dialogues.text: is tacked onto a wall. Alphabetical order. Alongside - date of capture. Mcst.on Day One. All the names are ringed, except Hilts, Hendley, Blythe, Bartlett, MacDonal Danny, Willie and Merivale. CAMERA REVEALS the SS officer sitting at a glistening desk sorting out reports. Grim. The phone rings.

dialogues.speaker: SS OFFICER
dialogues.text: Ja? (listens - smiles sardonically) Wunderschn. He replaces phone, rings Bartlett and MacDonald on the list, exits. .

dialogues.speaker: SS OFFICER 656
dialogues.text: enters. CAMERA REVEALS Bartlett and MacDonald. Both are manacled. They have been roughed up. .

dialogues.speaker: SS OFFICER
dialogues.text: We meet again. Bartlett and MacDonald stare at him stonily. SS OFFICER (continuing) . (hard) - You're going to wish you never . put us to all this trouble. (snaps in German ) Solitary confinement! Bartlett and MacDonald stare at him. .

dialogues.speaker: DANNY AND WILLIE 657
dialogues.text: are in the tiny boat, soft asleep, in the rushes that border the river bank. SOUND of searchers. Flicks of flashlignts. Danny wakes without moving. A touch and Willie is awake. SOUND of searchers coming nearer. Danny pantomimes - Shall we shove off? Willie shakes his head. They sink deeper into the boat. Flashlights seek. Dim figures. Helmeted soldiers, A bird is flushed suddenir, whirls away with beating wings. A burst of trigger happy machine guns...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ‘O

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A satellite field accomodating small general purpose and training aircraft.

dialogues.speaker: HENDLEY AND BLYTHE ' 659
dialogues.text: wearing mechanic's overalls, stroll up to the nose of a Junkers trainer that is lined up with several others. Quickly Hendley takes a crank from a locker on the side of the plane, inserts it near the back of the engine, stands Blythe next to it. ¢

dialogues.speaker: HENDLEY
dialogues.text: (quickly) . When I give you the word, you crank. After she starts don't move until I come for you or you'll get a mouthful of propeller. 658 Hendley gets into the plane, studies the controls and switches. HENDLEY (continuing) Blythe cranks and the motor catches. Hendley jumps. out of the plane and runs to Blythe's side, hurries him to the cockpit. He leoks off as shouts start. Contact!

dialogues.speaker: A SENTRY , . 660
dialogues.text: is gesticulating, shouting at them.

dialogues.speaker: TWO GERMAN MECHANICS 663
dialogues.text: come out of a nearby hangar, react - they start hurrying toward them. Then, as Hendley guns the plane - they begin to run. Hendley spins the plane, takes off straight down the taxi strip, struggles into the air.

dialogues.speaker: HENDLEY 662
dialogues.text: shakes his head at the wild takeoff. Levels the plane.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: as Hendley drops the plane down into a valley until he is barely skimming the ground. Approaches a ridge, zooms up over 1+, drops down again, follows the valley under cover of the ridges. (CONTINUED )

dialogues.speaker: HENDLEY
dialogues.text: (adjusts compass) Next stop Switzerland. The motor coughs. Hendley frowns, adjusts the throttle. It coughs again. The valley has begun to narrow. Hendley barely maintains altitude as the engine continues to lose power. HENDLEY (continuing) Not getting fuel... frantically checks controls) Got to be a booster pump somewheres... The encine coughs, sputters. HENDLEY (continuing) Do you know the German wore for pump or booster or fuel?

dialogues.speaker: BLYTHE
dialogues.text: No. Rendley locates a lever, puts Biythe's hand on it. HENDLEY ‘ ' God knows what this is, but pump it like hell. (engine stops) Never mind. Just hang on.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The plane skims over some houses, sets down hard on a narrow highway. Bounces, disappears behind a clump of trees.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: the plane goes off the road, plows through the field erashing into a ditch.

dialogues.speaker: HENDLEY 665
dialogues.text: Shakily crawls out of the cockpit. Pulls Blythe after him The plane begins to burn - a sudden explosion whirls Hendley off his feet...

dialogues.speaker: HENDLEY 667
dialogues.text: as half blinded by the flames, ne grabs Blythe pulling him to safety. Over comes the screams of police sirens, faintly excited gutteral voices. Shakily Hendley peers over the broken wing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: a line of German soldiers runs toward them.

dialogues.speaker: HENDLEY- BLYTHE
dialogues.text: Hendley looks around desperately.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (urgently) Run for the trees. Without thinking, he takes off, his line of retreat cover by the wreck.. Blythe iooks around helplessly -- starts running, but instead of running to the trees, he runs int the open. A crackle of machine gun. Blythe crumples.

dialogues.speaker: EENDLEY 670
dialogues.text: stops running. Stares back aghast. Then, leaving the safety of his own retreat, heads for Blythe -- kneels | beside him. Over comes shouts in German of "hands up". ‘ BLYTHE I'm sorry ‘I messed it up for you, Hendley. He dies. Hendley gets to his feet grimly, raises his hands.

dialogues.speaker: LONG SHCT 671
dialogues.text: The harbor is filled with a variety of shipping, and the oes eranes of a working yard are silhouetted against the sky.

dialogues.speaker: DISSOLVE TO
dialogues.text: moves between the towering merchantmen. Danny and Willie stop at the stern of one, crane their necks to see where she hails from.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: which bears the name: “Nils Halvorsen, Trondheim".

dialogues.speaker: ROWBOAT . 674
dialogues.text: as it bobs in the water under the stern of the ship.

dialogues.speaker: WILLTE
dialogues.text: Swedish!

dialogues.speaker: DANNY
dialogues.text: Could be goons on board.

dialogues.speaker: WILLIE
dialogues.text: Shall we chance it?

dialogues.speaker: DANNY
dialogues.text: Got to. Can't row this out to sea. A shower of garbage descends on them.

dialogues.speaker: WILLIE
dialogues.text: (outraged) Hoi.

dialogues.speaker: WILLIE'S BOV 675
dialogues.text: at the. ship’s rail a cook is lowering his empty slop tub and raising a full one.

dialogues.speaker: WILLIE'S VOICE
dialogues.text: (louder) Hoi! . The. cook looks. down. . NEAR Th SHIP'S STERN - DANNY 676 pulls the rowboat out to where they can communicate with the cook.

dialogues.speaker: WILLIE
dialogues.text: Sprechen Sie Deutsch? - (no answer)

dialogues.speaker: DANNY
dialogues.text: Czi pan roscmawa po Polsku? (no answer)

dialogues.speaker: WILLIE
dialogues.text: (finally) Do you speak English? (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ig2.

dialogues.speaker: DANNY
dialogues.text: (horrible accent ) Parle vous Francais? No response from the cook.

dialogues.speaker: WILLIE
dialogues.text: (to Danny) Do you know any other language?

dialogues.speaker: DANNY
dialogues.text: I don't even know that one. They look off to see a ‘patrol boat approaching. It flies the Reich flag, carries guns mounted forward and is manne ’ py Navy personnel. Danny and Willie exchange glances. A decision. Then Danny looks up at the rail and makes the V for Victory sign. ‘he cook disappears. A moment. later, his head is back with that of another man who grins down and makes the V for Victory sign. A line comes over the side and dangles beside Danny and Willie who grab it and start pulling themselves up.

dialogues.speaker: ON THE DECK
dialogues.text: comes t> the rail beside the two men with the rope. From his manner it is apparent that he has observed what is -going on and it is also apparent that the two crew-men are not certain that his reaction will be favorable. As Danny and Willie come over the rail, they fece the office who studies them, expressionless. He looks at the patrsi boat which is coming around the bow of the ship now, and then back at Danny and Willie who stand before him un- certainly. Then the officer, moving quickly, seizes a heavy piece of iron from the deck and drops it into the rowboat. From this height it plummets straight through the bottom, leaving a gaping hole. The water-logged row- >doat sinks to its gunwales, becomes practically invisibl in the siop of the waves on the water. The Naval patrol boat backs down to a stop alongside the merchantman. Danny and Willie duck down to the deck. On the patrol boat an officer calls out.

dialogues.speaker: GERMAN OFFICER
dialogues.text: Faben Sie einen plilmen kahn &isehen?

dialogues.speaker: SWEDISH OFFICER
dialogues.text: Ich sprache nicht Deutsch.. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: LO
dialogues.text: (makes rowing motions ) Ruderboot. (hands close together) {hold up . two fingers) Zwei Mamner. Klein. The slight grim smile comes over the Swedish officer's face as he watches the German holding his arm outstretche with his two fingers rigid in an unaware V for Victory sign.

dialogues.speaker: SWEDISH OFFICER
dialogues.text: (with strong accent - making gestures) V for Victory? The naval officer drops his arm with a loud expression of disgust. Orders his boat. underway.

dialogues.speaker: GERMAN OFFICER
dialogues.text: (muttering)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: es Trottel!! oS . . (a beat) So inen Bloedsinn dass er mich nicht verstehen will. The powerful patrol boat spins on its stern, roars away. The Swedish officer again makes the V for Victory sign after it. This time viciously, meaningfully. He turns to Danny and Willie.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: . English? (Willie nods - slowly) I speak oniy few words English. One is -- (he smiles warmly) - welcome.

dialogues.speaker: SEDGWICK 678
dialogues.text: end other POW's are uncomfortable, asleep. The cell door siams open. SS guards, jailers:

dialogues.speaker: SS MAN
dialogues.text: Wake up! You're all going now. Back to camp! Schnell! He roughly wakes a few and they are all herded out, grumbling, cursing...

dialogues.speaker: A TRUCK 679
dialogues.text: is waiting. Sedgwick and the others - now handcuffed - are herded onto it. Strangely, only a guard. Sedgwick, the last, reacts angrily as he is shoved. But the butt of the SS man's rifle cuts short his protest. He glances off - gasps...

dialogues.speaker: OTHER POW'S 680
dialogues.text: are being herded into two other trucks. Among them is Bartlett... or was it? SEDGWICK oo , 681

dialogues.speaker: . SEDGWICK
dialogues.text: Hey - I thought I saw Cyril! Pow's (crowding) Where? Over there? Couldn't be! You sure? But the SS guards drive them from the tail gate. Then two SS men get into the back of the truck, jerk their safety catches off ominously... ANOTHER “NGLE - THE THREE TRUCKS 682 begin t~ move. Head out ef the gates. Only a single car with armed SS.men per truck. Minimum security pre- cautions.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A few-cars and army trucks are parked. Glimmer of light as people come out, go in through the blackout curtains. Overhead is the drone of bombers. Distant crackle of ack ack. A shadow moves.

dialogues.speaker: RILTS 684
dialogues.text: is under a military car siphoning off some gasoline into a motorcycle's spare gas can. Now it is full. He screws on the stopper, pockets the length of rubber hose. Before he crawls away he jabs his pocket knife into one of the tires. Air hisses out.

dialogues.speaker: EXT, LONELY SECOND HIGHWAY
dialogues.text: A TRUCK a 685 with its single guard-car travels at high speed.

dialogues.speaker: INT, BACK OF TRUCK _- NIGHT
dialogues.text: “BARTLETT - MACDONALD 686 and several other escapees are sitting with their backs “against the sides. All are handcuffed. Very alert SS men watch them. All the POW's are drowsy, beat. : Ext. ANOTHER -HIGHWAY - NIGHT.

dialogues.speaker: THE OTHER TWO TRUCKS , 687
dialogues.text: with their single attendant guard-cars... INT. FIRST TRUCK - NIGHT .

dialogues.speaker: MORE DROWSY POW'S 688
dialogues.text: try to sleep fitfully. SS guards. ,

dialogues.speaker: INT, SECOND TRUCK
dialogues.text: MORE DROWSY POwW'S 689 as before. Dirty. Very tired. SS guards.

dialogues.speaker: THE TWO TRUCKS 690
dialogues.text: break their tandem. One truck and its guard car go left, the other right. Far off, searchlights seek the maraudirz night bombers.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: “or

dialogues.speaker: BARTLETT'S TRUCK 691
dialogues.text: goes more slowly now. Ahead is an enormous arched stone viaduct-like bridge. ANT. BACK OF ‘TRUCK - NIGHT

dialogues.speaker: . BARTLETT 692
dialogues.text: is awake, the rest asleep. His face mirrors grave concern. He doesn't notice MacDonald studying him.

dialogues.speaker: MACDONALD
dialogues.text: Cyril. Immediately Bartlett's concern evaporates.

dialogues.speaker: BARTLETT
dialogues.text: Can't you sleep?

dialogues.speaker: MACDONALD
dialogues.text: What's bothering you?

dialogues.speaker: BARTLETT
dialogues.text: (after pause) Well, I suppose I'ma little > Surprised. I expected a long stay in solitary at ' least. Or a single short trip. .

dialogues.speaker: MACDONALD
dialogues.text: (smiles) So you'll have to stay with us./ Is that so bad?

dialogues.speaker: BARTLETT
dialogues.text: (smiles - then: ) Just concerned about'all of you.and all the rest. Hope I haven't blotted seventy six ledgers.

dialogues.speaker: MACDONALD
dialogues.text: (easily) We're all over twenty one. Foot loose and fancy free. beat We'd never have done it without you. (smiles) For what it's worth, I think you did a damn good job.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: / 692 | CONTINUED: . “692 ‘O The truck turns sharply, begins to slow. Bartlett reac

dialogues.speaker: BARTLETT
dialogues.text: (to SS guard - in German) Where are we? Have we arrived?

dialogues.speaker: SS GUARD
dialogues.text: (curtly - in English) Here you will stretch your legs. Five minutes. It will be hours yet to reach Sagan. MacDonald brightens. Bartlett's face is impassive. The truck stops and the SS guards motion them out.

dialogues.speaker: BARTLETT'S TRUCK 693
dialogues.text: is on the dirt road which leads under the viaduct - fifty yards or so off the highway. The POW's get down awkwardly - of course, still manacled. The guard motions them off a few paces. He is joined by other guards. All carry burp oN guns. Watchful. BARTLETT - MACDONALD oo 694 Bartlett looks up at the night. .Distant ack ack. Other PoW's stretch tiredly, chat quietly.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I enjoy being alive. “Harry” and "Tom" and all the others kept me alive. I've never been happier. . (after pause) . You know, Mac...

dialogues.speaker: THE SS MEN 695
dialogues.text: Simultaneously they jerk their guns up - spray a long burst ¢2 bullets in a swath. The chatter carries over oO:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A crackle of machine guns - fainter. Nearby is parked the second of the POW trucks. The crackle of guns carries over to: :

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The third truck. Parked. The faint machine gun fire cuts as abruptly as it started. A grim faced SS man is collect ing shovels. He alone moves in the whole vista.

dialogues.speaker: HILTS 698
dialogues.text: comes over the rise. stops. It is very quiet. The motorcycle engine ticks smoothly.

dialogues.speaker: AHEAD 699
dialogues.text: is a small town. Roadblocked. Guards - an armored car - moteorcycled soldiers, Beyond is the border town and _ beyond that, the mountains. Freedom. The guards see him.

dialogues.speaker: HIDTS . 700
dialogues.text: looks around. Then grimly he buckles his helmet; jerks the motorcycle into motion.

dialogues.speaker: ROADBLOCK
dialogues.text: react. The armored car's machine gun covers Hilts as he approaches. <A sentry jumps up, a hundred yards from the roadblock, challenges Hilts. He gains speed. Then the armored car opens up with the machine gun...

dialogues.speaker: HILTS 702
dialogues.text: swerves, cuts off the road, careens on to a track as othe motorcycles and cars try to head him off. Hilts races, swerves, cuts through a clump of trees, soars off a rise, holds his machine erect as it bucks like a wild horse. Following is a burst of bullets. Hilts backtracks for the road, the others following wildly...

dialogues.speaker: HILTS
dialogues.text: as he drops-a gear and accelerates violently. Bullets spray the dirt and ricochet off the bike. He skids eruelly on the dirt and makes the road as three German motorcyclists turn a corner, race to intercept. Hilts opens the throttle and screams away, the German motor- eycles pursuing.

dialogues.speaker: TS 704
dialogues.text: broadsides a corner, approaching. The lead German motorcycle hits a wet patch, skids and a murderous pile up happens - the two other bikes smashing into a wall.

dialogues.speaker: HIGH WALLED ROAD
dialogues.text: throttles back as he comes to an intersection. Beyond, over a small wall is the Swiss border and the Swiss guard and the open read anc dwarfing them = the Alps. Freedom. Erightening, he turns left -- WaLLED ROAD 706 Hilts races down the tunnel like read turns right. Cul-de-sac! He turns, races down to the next turning - again turns right. This road leads him around in a circle.

dialogues.speaker: HILTS 707
dialogues.text: stops, almost frantic for now the Alps are right -- again blocked. Over comes the SOUND of approaching sirens. He races off, turns right in a nightmare dash.

dialogues.speaker: ANOTHER RGAD
dialogues.text: races, turns left. Skids to a stop as again he hits a cul-de-sac -- the Alps are now left again. The sirens are loucer. He backtracks. Screams right, then left.

dialogues.speaker: HILTS . 709
dialogues.text: impotently slows as he grinds into another cul-de-sac. Now the sirens are loud, he looks back -

dialogues.speaker: SOLDIERS
dialogues.text: have converged. block his escape.

dialogues.speaker: HILTS. 711
dialogues.text: instantly turns, jerks the throttle open and aimost kamakez-.s into the mass of men, motorcycles and cars. Th soldiers scatter - some are plowed under as he smashes in them, then riccochets off a car. The bike careens into th sky - Hilts flies off, falls half across a car, gets to h feet snakily, surprised he's still alive. Then he sees th four inert Germans, two others who are in agony, badly hu smiles grimly.. Soldiers jerk the actions of their burp guns. Hilts raises one hand = the other flips his collar insignia.

dialogues.speaker: GERMAN
dialogues.text: Amerikaner! Hilts raises both hands - waiting.

dialogues.speaker: A GERMAN STAFF CAR 712
dialogues.text: pulls up to the curb. Two German army majors and a German colonel get out, cross the sidewalk and sit down at one o the tables. The cafe terrace is deserted except for the waiter who approaches the German officers with every sign of pleasure and a lone occupant of a nearby table reading a-newsparer. The waiter bows and smiles as the three German officers make themselves comfortable.

dialogues.speaker: WAITER
dialogues.text: Bon jour, mesSieurs, bon jour. oo "A MAJOR * Bon jour, mon ami. ’ COLONEL Bon jour, Aristede. ‘WAITER Encore le meme chose? ‘COLONEL Oui, le meme chose pour tous. CLOSE : me 713 on the newspaper Courier De Toulouse being lowered. Merivale looks at the German officers, makes a mov2 as though to get out of there, thinks better of it. Hides behind his paper again.

dialogues.speaker: THE WAITER 714
dialogues.text: is at the bar as the proprietor pours three glasses of cognac. He takes the tray and goes back to the sidewalk where he serves the officers.

dialogues.speaker: WAITER
dialogues.text: Service. The waitsr now heads for Merivale. (CONTINUED )

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: _ WAITER (continuing) Monsieur,

dialogues.speaker: MERIVALE
dialogues.text: Oud? ‘ :

dialogues.speaker: WAITER
dialogues.text: Telephone.

dialogues.speaker: MERIVALE
dialogues.text: (covers his surprise) Telephone?

dialogues.speaker: . WAITER
dialogues.text: Oui, monsieur. Par ici, s'il vous plait.

dialogues.speaker: MERIVALE
dialogues.text: (nervous - suspicious) Pour moi?’ Vous etes - uh - sur?

dialogues.speaker: WAITER
dialogues.text: Oud, monsieur. Suivez moi, stil vous plait. — The Waiter pauses till Merivale gets up nervously, then leads him into the cafe. . : an

dialogues.speaker: THE WAITER 715
dialogues.text: leads Merivale into the empty cafe and around the bar to a telephone on the shelf.

dialogues.speaker: WAITER
dialogues.text: Voila, monsieur. The waiter 6lances at his watch and then at the street ©.S. aS werivale Joins him behind the bar and picks up the phone.

dialogues.speaker: MERIVALE
dialogues.text: Allo? Alls? Merivale sees something at his feet behind the bar. c

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: of the proprietor crouched behind the bar. Merivale turns <> the waiter. MERIVALE (pointing) Er - uh - qu'est - ce-que -? Before Merivale has a chance to finish, the waiter grabs him and forces him down behind the bar.

dialogues.speaker: A CAR 717
dialogues.text: cruising slowly past the cafe. There is a burst of gunfire. The bar window dissolves and the three German officers slump to the table and fall to the floor. The car picks up speed.

dialogues.speaker: MERIVALE 718
dialogues.text: the waiter and the proprietor behind the bar.

dialogues.speaker: MERIVALE
dialogues.text: Dites moi - dites moi que - look I don't speak French very well. Do either of you speak English?

dialogues.speaker: WAITER
dialogues.text: A little.

dialogues.speaker: MERIVALE
dialogues.text: I'm a British officer. I've escaped from prison camp. I'm trying to cross the border to Spain. Do you understand? Can you help me?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No. But I know samen who can.

dialogues.speaker: A DIM GROUP OF FIGURES 719
dialogues.text: approach. As they come up the rise - behind them rolling hills - they are seen more clearly. One is Merivale, the others are French in the berets of the Maquis. They point forward. Then their faint voices: (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 719 720 721 The boy considers this. Then: 203.

dialogues.speaker: VOICES
dialogues.text: Adieu m'sieu. Bon chance. They turn and leave Merivale. Alone.

dialogues.speaker: MERIVALS 720
dialogues.text: is very tired. ‘Travel stained. He peers into the growing darkness, Footsteps. ANOTHER ANGLE - A SMALL SPANISH BoY 721 . appecrs. Beyond him are the Pyrenees.

dialogues.speaker: BOY
dialogues.text: You are the English officer?

dialogues.speaker: MERIVALE
dialogues.text: Yes.

dialogues.speaker: BOY
dialogues.text: I am your guide, senor.

dialogues.speaker: MERIVALE
dialogues.text: (tired smile) Welcome, young sir, Very. much welcome. .

dialogues.speaker: BOY
dialogues.text: (studies him, then points off) That is Spain.

dialogues.speaker: MERIVALE
dialogues.text: Yes. But it's more than that - to me.

dialogues.speaker: BOY
dialogues.text: Where do you come from - back there?

dialogues.speaker: MERTIVALE
dialogues.text: Some would call it hell - some would call it life. (beat) - I'd call it the past. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: BOY
dialogues.text: (after pause) My father says the past is the present, and a little of the future, but lived today as always.

dialogues.speaker: MERIVALE
dialogues.text: (gravely) | He is a wise man. Ferhaps others can be as wise. The boy studies him, then smiles a little smile.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Now there is only the mountain and the cloud-fillec dusk and the tiny figures of the man and the boy on the breast of the mountain. They crest together. Man and boy. Gently. Into freedom.

dialogues.speaker: DISSOLVE TO
dialogues.text: Lm, VON LUGER'S OFFICE - DAY

dialogues.speaker: VON LUGER 723
dialogues.text: is sitting at his desk, looking at a sheet of paper. He does not loox up as Ramsey enters. He does not return his salute. He does nothing except stare at -the paper, - his face sagged.

dialogues.speaker: VON LUGER
dialogues.text: (almost inaudibly - under great stress) Eleven more of your men are being returned today.

dialogues.speaker: RAMSEY
dialogues.text: Who?

dialogues.speaker: VON LUGER
dialogues.text: I do not have that information. (pause) I.- I am directed - by higher authority to inform you that - that fifty of your officers were shot while escaping. (CONTINUED )

dialogues.speaker: RAMSEY
dialogues.text: (appalled) Fifty?

dialogues.speaker: VON LUGER
dialogues.text: Yheir - their effects will be returned.

dialogues.speaker: RAMSEY
dialogues.text: (pause) How many were wounded?

dialogues.speaker: VON LUGER
dialogues.text: (offers him paper) Here are the names. Of the dead.

dialogues.speaker: RAMSEY
dialogues.text: (harder) How many were wounded?

dialogues.speaker: VON LUGER
dialogues.text: None. Ramsey's face closes, VON. LUGER (continuing). They - the higher authority just directs me to inform you that fifty were --

dialogues.speaker: RAMSEY
dialogues.text: Murdered! He coldly takes the paper, exits without saluting - without clesing the door.

dialogues.speaker: A TRUCK
dialogues.text: approaches. Stops outside the gate. The remainder of the escapees, including Hendley (excluding Hilts), tiredl get out. POW's inside the wire begin to collect. The main gate swings open and the men walk in.

dialogues.speaker: RAMSEY 725
dialogues.text: comes out on to the veranda, stops, glances off to see the arrivals. Then he begins to read the list. Impassive.

dialogues.speaker: A GESTAPO CAR 726
dialogues.text: “CO approaches, stops. Two Gestapo civilians and SS guard get out and enter the Headquarters building. Pass Ramsey, @ look between them. He exits toward compound.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 727 ‘THE Pow's 727 mill around the returnees. Hendley is there. Ramsey walks up -- his face a mask. Hello, Hendley!

dialogues.speaker: HENDLEY
dialogues.text: (sensing Ramsey's inner misery) What's the matter, sir?

dialogues.speaker: RAMSEY
dialogues.text: They shot fifty. Murdered them.

dialogues.speaker: _ RENDLEY
dialogues.text: : wat? (appalled) rv at?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ramsey turns to Sorren.

dialogues.speaker: . . RAMSEY
dialogues.text: Post the list. Sorren stares at it, horrified, then exits.

dialogues.speaker: HENDLEY
dialogues.text: Cyril?

dialogues.speaker: RAMSEY
dialogues.text: : Yes. . (beat) What happened to Colin?

dialogues.speaker: HENDLEY
dialogues.text: He bought it -- Cyril was right. But the fifty! What a waste! Ramsey studies hin. As grave. Sound of a car approaching - they look off.

dialogues.speaker: A MILITARY CAR 728
dialogues.text: stops outside the main gate. Hilts gets out under guard. He heads for the gate -~ looks off, reacts.

dialogues.speaker: HENDLEY AND RAMSEY 729
dialogues.text: also stare off.

dialogues.speaker: VON LUGER 730
dialogues.text: hatless, is coming down the steps of the Headquarters Building his arms behind him, escorted by the Gestapo and SS men. Posen following - white and nervous. The main gate guards half begin to salute, stop appalled as they see. Von Luger's wrists are in handcuffs. At the Gestapo car he stops, looks at Ramsey.

dialogues.speaker: RAMSEY
dialogues.text: Ramsey stares back, stonily. And Hendley. Pow's 732 near the list. Stare at it, stunned. Then Sorren turns -- sees the Gestapo men. Others see them. The whole group begins to move to the main gate. Ominously. A mutter of anger.

dialogues.speaker: GESTAPO MEN ' , 733
dialogues.text: react. “The beginning of fear. One. looks around, then sees Hilts, alone, outside the fence.

dialogues.speaker: GESTAPO MAN
dialogues.text: You! Get in the camp! At onee! Go! Hilts walks over, GESTAPO MAN (continuing) I said in the canp, Dumkopf! Hilts suddenly belts him. GUARDS . 73h react, startled. .

dialogues.speaker: SS MEW 735
dialogues.text: jerk their guns around. Posen is petrified.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 738 739- gf a THO

dialogues.speaker: POW'S
dialogues.text: surge forward to ring the gate. The beginning of an angry roar and preparation for a suicidal rush. The Gestapo man gets to is feet, backs, white with rage. A deadiy second. Fear with the SS men.

dialogues.speaker: THE GESTAPO MAN 737
dialogues.text: hesitates, then turns away, curtly orders Von Luger into the car. Von Luger looks at Hilts who lonks back. A moment, then with renewed dignity, Von Luger obeys. The car drives away. Posen looks at Hilts.

dialogues.speaker: POSEN
dialogues.text: (nervously) Cooler! He exits as Hilts walks eff. Two guards fali in step.

dialogues.speaker: RAMSEY AND HENDLEY 738
dialogues.text: stare off. Then glance at... THEIR PCy - POSEN 739 Stands on the stoop of the veranda looking out over the camp. Alone, drawn.

dialogues.speaker: RAMSEY
dialogues.text: our new CO! : Hendley reacts, then glances around the camp thoughtfully

dialogues.speaker: HENDLEY
dialogues.text: Where's Kramer? Werner? And where's Strachwitz?

dialogues.speaker: RAMSEY
dialogues.text: Eastern front. Sorren comes up behind them.

dialogues.speaker: SORREN
dialogues.text: (to Hendley) I'm the new Big "X", Hendley. There are some things we'll need. There is a meeting in the library.

dialogues.speaker: HENDLEY
dialogues.text: I'm your boy. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: Sorren exits. Hendley begins to exit, turns back to . Ramsey. . HENDLEY (continuing) Sir, do you know if anyone got away?

dialogues.speaker: RAMSEY
dialogues.text: No we don't yet. (thoughtfully) You know, Hendley, Cyril's Teal idea was to get back at the enemy the only way we could. He certainly did that here but we have only rumors about the out- side.

dialogues.speaker: HENDLEY
dialogues.text: Sir, it was monumental. They must have ased a million grons.

dialogues.speaker: RAMSEY
dialogues.text: Good. Good.

dialogues.speaker: HENDLEY
dialogues.text: l (after pause) we Do you think it was worth the oO _price, sir?

dialogues.speaker: RAMSEY
dialogues.text: I'd say.that depends on your point of view, Hendley.

dialogues.speaker: HENDLEY
dialogues.text: Yes, sir. A pause, then he exits.

dialogues.speaker: THE COOLER
dialogues.text: goes in. The door clangs... 742. LIBRARY - SORREN AND HENDLEY The enter as do other members of "X". s

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 743 Tad

dialogues.speaker: RAMSEY 743
dialogues.text: turns his gaze from where Von Luger has gone. Then to... ITEADQUARTERS - POSEN 74d stands on the veranda, feels Ramsey's look, bleakly turns away, enters the building.

dialogues.speaker: THE COMPOUND 745
dialogues.text: the caged and the guarders of the cage. Men walk around the perimeter, near the warning wire, studying, planning - probing. Seeking a chink in the mesh of the cage. Constantly. Under a lowering sky. The rain begins. But the men within still walk and watch and wait and plan... FADE OUT.
